name: Prize
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansprize.

name: Rain
mnemonic: The towel is getting soaked with drops of liquid. That's because it'sraining. Get your towels and other clothes inside before they get soaked through from this rain!

mnemonic_image.alt: Cloud above a folded towel. Raindrops falling in background, with four prominent drops on the towel. Radical overlays the cloud base, the center, top edge, and sides of the towel, and the four central rain drops.

name: Mole
mnemonic: There's trash on some dirt that seems to be... moving? If you lift up that trash you'll find amolein the dirt! Moles like to dig around underground and look for stuff to grab (like trash). They're the raccoons of the ground.

name: Building
mnemonic: This radical looks like a curvy letter B. What does B stand for?Building! This radical often shows up in kanji related to gatherings or to places where people come together… like buildings.

mnemonic_image.alt: Building viewed from front, shaped like a tall, narrow letter B, with the building radical outlining it.

name: Wedding
mnemonic: This radical looks like someone wearing a giant dress who has a tear in their eye. This is a person at theirwedding. That explains the big dress and the tear (of happiness!) in their eye.

name: Syrup
mnemonic: The products trees make? That'ssyrup. Delicious maple syrup, for example. Mmmm!

name: Five
mnemonic: If you use your imagination, this radical actually looks like the number "5." You just have to remove the vertical line in the bottom left, plus a few extra ends that stick out here and there. Once you do that, you have an easy way to remember that this radical meansfive.

mnemonic_image.alt: Animation showing how the Arabic numeral 5 can resemble the radical, by writing the number 5 using only straight lines, with a top line that sticks out on the left and a closed square shape at the bottom.

name: Violence
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansviolence.

name: Interval
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansinterval.

name: Mona Lisa
mnemonic: This radical looks like a combination of the brush radical (聿) and the beauty kanji (美). So what's something beautiful you can paint with a brush? The most famous is probably theMona Lisa.

name: Satellite
mnemonic: Look at this radical. Can you see it floating in space? Can you see the antennae and reflectors? That's because it's asatellite.

name: Tree
mnemonic: Do you see thetreein here? It has branches, and then it has the foliage coming down diagonally from it, spreading out like a tree would. That's why this radical is a tree.

mnemonic_image.alt: Fir tree. Branches stick out to the sides along the radical’s horizontal line, while under them more branches fan out in two diagonal lines.

name: Ladle
mnemonic: There's aladlescooping up two drops of liquid. See the handle and the scoop part of the ladle? Imagine ladling some water into your mouth. Mmm.

mnemonic_image.alt: Ladle standing upright, two drops splashing to the left. Radical lines overlay drops, ladle handle, and scoop.

name: Person
mnemonic: This is aperson. They're standing with their arms down at their sides and their legs spread out, which kind of makes them look like a torso with a pair of legs. Think of人as highlighting the bipedal nature of people. Walking on two legs? Probably a person.

mnemonic_image.alt: A person facing you, standing with their arms at their sides and their legs spread out wide, with a radical overlay outlining their silhouette.

name: Task
mnemonic: This looks like a little whiteboard to keep track of yourtasks for the day. It's got three little legs on the bottom. And see those blank squares? They're sticky notes you can write your tasks on. Work tasks, school tasks, WaniKani reviews… So what are your tasks for today? Imagine putting them in those little squares.

mnemonic_image.alt: A three legged whiteboard with four sticky notes on it, labeled To Dos and with tasks written on them. The radical overlays the three legs and four square grid.

name: Gold
mnemonic: Underneath that hat are two bars ofgold, but under those there are some spikes. This is some kind of trap for people who try to take your gold. And why else would you make a trap? Everyone wants to protect their gold.

mnemonic_image.alt: Conical hat above two gold bars, shorter one on top. Below, three spikes on the ground, two side ones flaring outward. Radical overlays sides of the hat, gold bars, spikes, and ground.

name: Peoples
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanspeoples.

name: Chinese
mnemonic: This is theChineseradical. Why? Because it looks like a traditional Chinese pagoda! One of those towers with a bunch of tiered roofs, you know? Sure, lots of Asian countries have pagodas, but let's be honest — the Chinese probably came up with them first.

mnemonic_image.alt: A four level Chinese pagoda. Radical lines overlay each level.

name: Private
mnemonic: This is a little triangle that's almost completely closed off. When you want to be alone, you hide in a place where you can be inprivate. That's why this is the private radical. You're closing yourself off to the rest of the world, with just a little peephole.

mnemonic_image.alt: A girl inside the triangular shape of the radical, peeking out of its opening on the right side.

name: Stomach
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansstomach.

name: King
mnemonic: This is thekingradical. Picture this king sitting on his solid, squarish throne. The top stroke is the high back of the throne. The cross in the middle is his body, with his arms spread out on the arm rests. The bottom stroke is the ground. See him sitting there now, looking all dignified. Talk about a kingly king.

mnemonic_image.alt: King sitting on his throne, facing you. The radical, a vertical line with three horizontal lines spaced evenly along it, overlays the image of the king.

name: Nine
mnemonic: If you look at this radical in just the right way, you'll notice that it kind of looks like the letters "n" and "i" (the "i" comes from the little flippy-up stroke on the right side). What do the letters "n" and "i" start spelling? Why, the wordnine.

mnemonic_image.alt: Uppercase N and lowercase I, written in cursive. The radical overlay is more angular, but roughly aligns with the N and bottom half of the I.

name: Animal
mnemonic: This looks like a tail with some hairs coming off of it. It shouldn't be confused with fingers though, because it's curved, and the things sticking out are more erratic, like hair or fur would be. That's why this radical is theanimalradical.

name: Hills
mnemonic: See the rollinghillswith the road going off into the background to another hill? That's why this is the hills radical.

name: Elf
mnemonic: You see a leaf ear, better known as anelf! Elves are just humans who have ears that are pointy like leaves.

name: Samurai
mnemonic: Thesamurairadical looks a lot like the dirt radical. The difference is this one has a longer top horizontal line, which is for those broad warrior shoulders. The bottom line is also shorter, since it's the little cushion the samurai is sitting on. Samurai didn't just fight, you know. They sat on cushions and wrote poems and stuff too. This is a very sensitive samurai.

mnemonic_image.alt: Samurai with top knot and broad shouldered outfit, sitting in seiza on a cushion. The radical overlays the line of his shoulders, upright head and body, and small floor cushion.

name: Trash
mnemonic: There's a lid on top of something you're trying to keep private. It's yourtrash. You wouldn't want people going through your private trash, which is why we put lids on our trash cans. It's also illegal to look through someone's trash, so make sure you never do that.

mnemonic_image.alt: Trash can lid above a triangular bag of trash, which sits atop a trash can. Lid radical overlays lid, private radical overlays bag of trash.

name: Spider
mnemonic: If you look closely and carefully, sometimes you can see some private legs in winter. Whose legs?Spiderlegs! It's too cold for them in winter, so they hide in cracks and crevices, but sometimes you can see their little leggies sticking out anyway.

name: Cheap
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanscheap.

name: Drum
mnemonic: This radical is made up of samurai and beans. Samurai used to put beans indrums so they could tap and shake them to make noise. Can you imagine shaking and tapping this drum radical?

name: Younger Brother
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansyounger brother.

name: Woman
mnemonic: This radical looks like a woman curtsying. Another way to think of it could be as two stacked Xs, since women generally have XX chromosomes.

mnemonic_image.alt: Woman curtsying, facing to the left, with arms raised to hold up the hem of her skirt. The radical lines roughly match her head, horizontal arms, and crossed legs.

name: Bird
mnemonic: See the cool wing on the bottom? See the head with the neat feather coming out of the top? This is abird. Tweet tweet!

mnemonic_image.alt: Fat bird facing your left, tuft of feathers on head, wings pointed out under beak. Radical lines overlay head, body, and wings.

name: Cactus
mnemonic: See thecactuscoming out of the ground? It's happy to see you!

name: Wing
mnemonic: See thewing? It's kind of like a bat wing with webbing. Either way, it's just a wing.

mnemonic_image.alt: Bat wing extended to your right. Radical lines overlay arm and each finger.

name: Former
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansformer.

name: Center
mnemonic: Remember the guy from the big radical? Here he's bending his arms up to fasten some kind of belt, right across thecenterof his body. It's one of those belts that just goes across your waist, which is actually perfect for such a big guy, since he really needs to secure his center (of gravity).

mnemonic_image.alt: Lanky man with long seat belt across his lap, legs flared outward under it. His hands grasp the belt, arms bent at ninety degree angles, forming two squares above the belt. The radical overlays him and the belt.

name: Mouth
mnemonic: A big, gaping, square hole represents someone opening their giantmouthto tell you something stupid.

mnemonic_image.alt: Open mouth with just the lips showing, not round but angular, to echo the square shape of the radical.

name: Feathers
mnemonic: This radical already looks like a pair of rectangularfeathers, right? I guess those short lines in each feather are like the filaments of the feathers.

mnemonic_image.alt: Two rectangular feathers, the radical outlining their top, right, and bottom edges. In each feather, two short diagonal strokes tilting in towards the feather's right edge.

name: Power
mnemonic: Imagine a guy flexing his arm downward to show off his steroid-pumped arm. It's huge. It's so full ofpower. RARRRWWWRRR!!

mnemonic_image.alt: Upper body of a muscleman facing you and flexing his arm on your right. The radical overlays the sloping vertical line of his body, the horizontal line of his shoulders, with a sloping vertical line for his biceps on the right.

name: Attach
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansattach.

name: Mix
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansmix.

name: Storehouse
mnemonic: Your flowers become your servants. You plant them, you water them, you bring them up, then you cut them down and put them in yourstorehouse. They do what you want because they become YOUR servants, not the other way around. That's why you can tell them to sit in the storehouse where they wait until you come to eat them.

name: Icicle
mnemonic: This ice is in the shape of a stick. It's anicicle!

name: Umbrella
mnemonic: This radical looks like anumbrella, specifically just the handle part. A good old curvy umbrella handle, so you can hang that umbrella on your arm when it stops raining.

mnemonic_image.alt: Handle of a closed umbrella, curling to your right. Some umbrella canopy is visible above it, but the radical overlays just the handle.

name: Fingers
mnemonic:
This looks like a long index finger bent at the bottom, with several other stubby fingers growing out of it on either side. That makes it thefingersradical. A bit creepy, but imagine how easily you could grip something or scratch your back with fingery fingers like these. Pretty nice, right?
This is also a lot like the hand radical (手) but smaller. And what are the smaller parts of a hand? The fingers! You can remember it that way too, if you want.

mnemonic_image.alt: Long finger shown vertically, its fingertip at the bottom, curled up to the left to match the radical. It has two short fingers growing out of each side, overlaid by two short horizontal radical lines.

name: Prison
mnemonic: This looks like an enclosure of sorts — that's why it's aprison. Imagine a tiny prisoner curled up inside, staring off into space, completely convinced they're trapped forever. Ironically this prison is actually wide open. They're just so consumed with self-pity that they haven't realized they've been free to leave all along.

mnemonic_image.alt: Prison walls in the shape of the radical, like an angular C, but rotated so the opening is on the bottom left. The shape partially surrounds a prisoner sitting on the curled up bottom edge.

name: Narwhal
mnemonic: This radical looks like anarwhal. See the tail at the bottom, and the majestic narwhal horn poking out at the top? It also looks like the katakana characterナ(na), so you can remember it that way too. Na-na-na-narwhal! Just be careful not to confuse this with the treasure radical (メ). The sideways line for that one is at more of a downward angle, like an "X." But the sideways line for narwhal is horizontal (ナ).

mnemonic_image.alt: Narwhal, its horn pointing straight up and its flippers spread out to match the radical shape, a horizontal line passing through a vertical line that curves gently to the left, like a narwhal tail.

name: History
mnemonic: This is thehistoryradical. You can see a textbook and a couple crossed swords. Because that's basically how history works — fight battles, record the results, and do it all over again. History!

mnemonic_image.alt: Open textbook, two swords crossed below it, tips overlapping the pages. Textbook shows Japan map and samurai helmet. Radical lines overlay square book, its center crease, and swords.

name: Ability
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansability.

name: See
mnemonic: This eye has legs, since you have to let your eyes run over something in order toseeit. That's why those eyes need legs — to see. They're wandering eyes, they want to see the world!!

mnemonic_image.alt: Disembodied eyeball with two legs protruding from the bottom and running to your left. The eye radical overlays the eyeball, and the legs radical overlays the legs, forming the see radical.

name: Hole
mnemonic: You have a roof on top of what looks like a volcano. What's the roof covering? It's definitely covering theholeat the top. I guess someone thought if they built a roof on the hole, none of the lava could come out. But isn't there a hole in the chimney? Guess their theory had someholesin it… Oh no, now lava is coming through the hole. RUN!!! RUN!!!!!!!!

mnemonic_image.alt: Roof radical balanced on a volcano, lava bubbling out of the roof's chimney. The hole radical overlays the chimney and roof, plus the steep sloping sides of the volcano.

name: Specialty
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansspecialty.

name: Fins
mnemonic: These look likefins. What's a pair of disembodied fins doing here?! Some fish must have left them here by accident. Bet they're really missing these fins right about now.

mnemonic_image.alt: Pair of fins shown side by side, matching the two diagonal strokes of the radical.

name: Nose
mnemonic: If you look at this radical right, you'll see aNOSE(with a squinty eye on the left).

name: Wheat
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji, but you learned that a really long time ago, so here's a reminder of the mnemonic, just in case:
What gives you life during the winter? It's thewheatyou store away.

name: Tombstone
mnemonic: There is a stool sticking out of the dirt. You walk up and realize it has writing on it. It's actually atombstone. You can sit on it and remember the people who are below the dirt now.

mnemonic_image.alt: Stool with letters R.I.P. written on it, set on a mound of dirt. Tombstone radical overlays stool and dirt.

name: Skewer
mnemonic: There's a stick going through some juicy meat. This is askewer.

name: Charcoal
mnemonic: When the sun gets small, you need to heat up by throwing some big horns in the fire. This turns into charcoal. Nice, toastycharcoalthat keeps you warm when the sun gets small.

name: Omen
mnemonic: There's an explosion around your legs. It was just as the fortune teller warned. This is theomenshe was talking about. Think about what happens after the omen hits. What horrible fortune teller magic will happen???

name: Pope
mnemonic: This is thepoperadical. Why? Because it looks like a pope hat! This one's got a big old cross on top, and it can only be worn by the pope.

mnemonic_image.alt: Cross with wide horizontal line, resting atop a pope hat. Cross radical overlays the cross, eye radical overlays the hat, combining to make the pope radical.

name: Easy
mnemonic: Flying to the sun with wings iseasy! Or so Icarus thinks. Someone should probably tell him…

mnemonic_image.alt: Icarus with wings flying up toward the sun. Sun covered in center by cloud. Sun radical overlays sun. Lines overlay Icarus’s shoulders and wings.

name: Tiger
mnemonic: You lost seven toes on a cliff, but you consider yourself lucky considering you got them taken off by the clifftigerthat lives in the area. Imagine a tiger taking your seven toes as you hang off the edge of a cliff if it helps. Exciting! (And also painful!)

name: Night
mnemonic: See that lid on top? It's actually a flying saucer. "Take me to your leader," say the aliens inside, arriving from a strange-looking moon. When do you think you'd see something like this? Atnight. When people see UFOs or the moon, it's usually night. That's why this is the night radical.

mnemonic_image.alt: Alien in flying saucer hovering above a leader on left, strange clouded moon on right. Radical overlays saucer, leader, moon, and clouds.

name: Oversee
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansoversee.

name: Sheep
mnemonic: This is a very fluffysheep. See the two horns poking up and all its wool poking out to the side? It's so fluffy that you can hardly see its tiny little legs. What a cute sheep!

mnemonic_image.alt: Wide sheep facing you, horns on head, two legs together in center. Three radical lines in body bisected in center, two overlaying horns.

name: Bundle
mnemonic: This looks like a tree with something tied around its middle, holding it tight. If you untied that middle part you'd realize it's actually a bunch of little trees (aka twigs and sticks) tied in abundle!

mnemonic_image.alt: Bundle of sticks tied together by a string that makes a bow. Radical overlays vertical bundle and bow.

name: Tall
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanstall.

name: Cape
mnemonic: This is acape, like the kind a superhero would wear. Use your imagination to picture a hero facing left, with a cape tied around their neck and hanging down their back. With that cape on, they're ready to save the world!

mnemonic_image.alt: Muscular superhero wearing cape facing your left. Cape rests on shoulders and down back. Radical lines overlay cape.

name: River
mnemonic: This radical already looks like ariver. See how the lines represent the flow of the river? There's even a slight bend in this river. So when you see this radical, you should think "river."

mnemonic_image.alt: Overhead view of a river flowing vertically, its banks shown on either side. The three lines of the radical match the banks and the center line of the river flow.

name: Sickle
mnemonic: Most of this radical is just the rice radical, but the top part is something coming to cut the rice from its stalk. That, my friend, is thesickle. See how the rice is still there? That's because it's in motion. The sickle is literally doing the cutting RIGHT NOW! (And don't confuse this with the grain禾radical!)

mnemonic_image.alt: Blade from sickle cutting top of rice plant. Slide radical overlays blade. Rice radical overlays plant.

name: Now
mnemonic: This is the radical fornow. It's a bit tough to see, but it kind of looks like a fancy clock. The𠆢is the top part hanging over the clock. Theラshows a triangular clock face with a little cuckoo on top, peeking out to tell you this means now — right now!

mnemonic_image.alt: Pendulum clock with gable roof, formed by two sloping radical lines. Under it, a short line drawn as a platform for a cuckoo. The clock face below is an inverted triangle, its top and right sides overlaid by the radical.

name: Stone
mnemonic: A leaf growing out of a… mouth?? Look again and see the mouth is actually made ofstone. The leaf here was just growing out of a crack on the side. Makes this stone mouth sculpture look kinda elegant, if you ask me. And obviously leaves don't grow on mouths, so whenever you see a leaf on a mouth, remember it's gotta be stone.

mnemonic_image.alt: The lily pad of the leaf radical with its stem coming out of the square mouth of the mouth radical, which is under the leaf. The mouth is made of stone, like that of a stone lion.

name: Rejoice
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansrejoice.

name: Loiter
mnemonic: The leader (ｲ) radical has a little something extra on top of him — he's got a casual cap on because it's his day off. And what does he like to do on his day off? He likes toloiter. Look at him just loitering around. What a loiterer.

mnemonic_image.alt: Person with ball cap, brim tilted down and left. Arms open, one tilted up and right, pressed against a wall. Other down and left, holding a smartphone. Radical overlays cap, arms, and body from the neck down.

name: Lifeguard
mnemonic: You have a task to save two kinds of lives. Who saves two kinds of lives? Alifeguard. They save the lives of people drowning, and then the lives of the people who go to try to help them. Picture a lifeguard saving the lives of two people at once. What a hero!

name: Blood
mnemonic: You see a little drop of something on your plate. Oh no… it'sBLOOD!!! Yep, you're bleeding. Now you have to wash that plate again — just as soon as the bleeding stops. Don't worry, your platelets should stop the bleeding soon. Haha, get it? PLATE-lets? Like blood platelets? Japanese blood jokes.

mnemonic_image.alt: Drying rack holding three plates. Drop over middle plate. Radical lines overlay rack, plates, and drop.

name: Exit
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansexit.

name: Buddy
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansbuddy.

name: Idea
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansidea.

name: Fish
mnemonic: This is afish. Kind of a funny-looking fish, with a weird head on top, a squat scaly body, and a tail fanning out underneath it. See the fish? Yeah, you see it.

mnemonic_image.alt: Fish standing upright with large tail fin flared out. Prison radical overlays head. Rice paddy radical over body. Boil radical over fins.

name: Death
mnemonic: There's a lid on a lion. And you're stuck under the lid with the lion, which means you will surely meet yourdeath. Or if you don't want to die, think of the poor lion. If you leave a lion under a lid for too long, death will come for it too. Either way, somebody's gonna die today.

mnemonic_image.alt: Lion with open mouth in L-shape. Lid rests on lion’s nose. Inside mouth, dead body and ghost. Lid radical and lion radical overlay.

name: Cross
mnemonic: This radical looks like across. I mean, just look at it. Two bars going through each other = a cross!

mnemonic_image.alt: Cross with arms of equal length to match the radical shape.

name: Say
mnemonic: There are a bunch of lines coming out of a mouth. Think of them as speech lines in a little speech bubble. Those lines represent the things yousay.

mnemonic_image.alt: Open lips, speaking. Above them, a word balloon with four squiggly lines. Second line from top wider than others. Radical traces the four lines and the lips.

name: Heart
mnemonic: Take a good look at this one. It kind of looks like aheart. Not the heart emoji kind, but a real-deal beating heart. Basically, there's a lump in the middle (the heart), and three lines that make up the arteries. Okay, so it's not the most anatomically correct heart, but just look at those floppy arteries going in and out, doing their thing and keeping you alive. What's not to love?

mnemonic_image.alt: Human heart with a smiley face on it, cradled in the L like shape in the middle of the radical, with three smaller lines above and either side of it drawn as arteries.

name: Meat
mnemonic: This is the radical formeat. What's meat-like about this? Think of a nice square slab of meat with some beautiful人-shaped marbling lines in it. Seeing it now? Mmm, meat.

mnemonic_image.alt: Square shape with open bottom, drawn as a slab of meat. Inside, two person radicals, one just above the other, drawn as marbling lines within the meat.

name: Go
mnemonic: You have the radicals for loiter, two, and barb. Someone who uses two barbs on you while you're loitering really wants you toGO!! GO on, stop loitering outside of my convenience store, ya dang kids!

mnemonic_image.alt: Man from loiter radical, fleeing to the left, the two radical drawn behind his head as speed lines. Under that the barb radical, drawn as a double barb. The elements combine to make the go radical.

name: Request
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansrequest.
Here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: Look at the ground! You spilled some water drops, so I request that you wipe them up. I'd do it myself, but you're the one who spilled them, so I'm requesting that you do it. Pretty reasonable request, right?

mnemonic_image.alt: Rag on ground, large drops of water shown under it. Finger points at rag as if making pushy request. Radical overlays finger, ground line, and drops.

name: Helicopter
mnemonic: This radical looks like ahelicoptercoming straight at you, doesn't it? You can't see the tail part because it's behind the bigger front cab of the helicopter. But you can see the front windows and the big spinning blade on top.

mnemonic_image.alt: Helicopter viewed head on. Horizontal line for blade. Two vertical lines come down off its middle, connect to net radical which overlays the helicopter face.

name: Barb
mnemonic: This radical is shaped like abarb. Kind of like the barb you'd see on a barbed fishing hook. Imagine that thing getting stuck in your arm or something. Not exactly pleasant. Say out loud, "Oh dang, I got a barb stuck in me!" Alright, relax, it's only a little barb.

mnemonic_image.alt: A barb, shown as a vertical line curling up to the left at the bottom, to match the radical overlay.

name: Shuriken
mnemonic: See theshurikenstuck into the ground? In case you don't know, a shuriken is just a throwing star. Awesome ninjas use them. That's what's in this radical.

name: Yoga
mnemonic: This looks like someone sitting with their back straight and a leg stretched out behind them. What kind of pose is this? Probably the kind you do inyoga. Sit on a yoga mat and make your body look like this radical. Nice, you're really doing yoga now.

mnemonic_image.alt: Woman in tank top and yoga pants, facing left in a half pigeon pose, one leg stretched out behind her. Radical overlays her upper body and leg.

name: Road
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansroad.

name: Jackhammer
mnemonic: Do you see the handles on the top and the barb on the bottom? It's ajackhammer. How can you tell? The two diagonal lines on the side show the motion of the jackhammer going up and down really fast, doing what jackhammers do. BBBHHRZHHHHRHHRZHZHHZH JUJUJUJUJU.

mnemonic_image.alt: A short jackhammer labeled JACK, diagonal motion lines on either side of it. Radical overlays jackhammer and motion lines.

name: Bathtub
mnemonic: See the dude sitting inside the box? His head is sticking out the top. That's abathtubhe's sitting in.

name: Lip Ring
mnemonic: This looks like something hooked around the corner of a mouth — it's alip ring! Use your imagination, because it's either a giant lip ring or a very small mouth. It's angular because kanji prefer straight lines, but try to picture it as the kind of studded, angular lip ring your trendy friend wore in high school.

mnemonic_image.alt: Open lips, studded lip ring on bottom left, mouth radical overlaying them. Horizontal line above it, with vertical line hooking down off its right end, drawn as an angular lip ring.

name: Dance
mnemonic: You see a cow in the evening. You get closer and realize it's doing adance. All cows dance in the evening. Can you picture it? The cow is dancing, so majestic, in the setting sunlight.

name: Window
mnemonic: See the criss-cross in the almost-square shape? That's the frames of a bigwindowyou can look out of. It's not perfectly shaped like a rice field, it's more artistic. That's why this is a window and田is not.

mnemonic_image.alt: Old window leaning to the right, less square than rhomboid. The radical overlays both its outer wooden frame and the cross shaped divider within, which supports the four window panes.

name: Towel
mnemonic: There's something draped over that stick. It's atowel! It's the kind of towel you clean with, so it's sort of old and crusty, which is why it holds its square shape even when it's hanging on the stick like that.

mnemonic_image.alt: Towel draped over the top point of a wooden stick. It covers most of the stick, falling squarely down around it. The radical overlays both the outline of the towel and the stick, including the part hidden by the towel.

name: Self
mnemonic: Remember the eye radical? Imagine that's your eye now, and there's a drop of paint falling into it, making your eye color unique. Now it's what makes you you. It's what makes you yourself.

mnemonic_image.alt: The vertical eye from the eye radical, with a drop radical attached to its top end, drawn as a drop of paint splashing into the eye. The radicals combine to make the self radical.

name: Announce
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansannounce.

name: Tsunami
mnemonic: A single drop (丶) is just water. But as soon as there are three, rising higher and higher, you know what's coming. Atsunami! Think of those drops as wave crests. Three whole tsunami waves, stacking up? That's a big tsunami.

mnemonic_image.alt: Three drop radicals in vertical formation, the bottom one with its right end tilted up. They overlay the crests of three waves stacked atop one another, making the tsunami radical.

name: Right
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansright.

name: Anti
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansanti.
Just in case you don't remember this, here's the kanji meaning mnemonic: Thestoolis in thecliff. If someone has a stool deep inside a cliff, they are most likely prettyantisociety, hiding away like that.

mnemonic_image.alt: Person sitting on stool under a low cliff, facing slightly right. Cliff radical overlays top and left cliff edges. Stool radical overlays person on stool.

name: Wrap
mnemonic: Yourself (oneself) is in prison. Look at the prison as it wraps around you. It wraps you up and holds you tight. That's why this is thewrapradical!

name: Conflict
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansconflict.

name: Legs
mnemonic: This radical already looks like a pair oflegs. There's even feet on these legs. That's how you know these are legs and not fins (or something else).

mnemonic_image.alt: Pair of legs, corresponding to the radical's two strokes, with feet in ballet slippers. The foot on your left is held back a little, its toe pointed. The foot on your right stands flat.

name: Stairs
mnemonic: This radical looks like a little flight ofstairs, don't you think? Also note it's being held up by a pillar or beam or something on the left side. After all, you don't want your stairs collapsing as you walk up them.

mnemonic_image.alt: Three steps supported by a slide shaped wooden pillar, with a tiny person climbing the steps. Radical overlays pillar and top two steps.

name: Enter
mnemonic: Watch out! This isn't the person radical, it's something else. What's the difference? The right side is longer than the left. This radical also has that extra part sticking out at the top. See it? It kind of looks like a person lowering their head to go inside a tent or something. That's why this radical isenter.

mnemonic_image.alt: Person walking to the left, legs spread mid stride, their head bowed in order to enter a tent. The radical overlays the person.

name: Fang
mnemonic: Imagine this in your mouth. It's one tooth that sticks out more than any other. It's yourfang. Can you see this sticking out of a wolf mouth instead? Try that if you can't picture yourself with a fang this cool.

name: Spicy
mnemonic: This is thespicyradical. See how it's wide at the top, with a little stem sticking up, and narrow at the bottom? Just like a chili pepper. It's so spicy it can't even handle its own heat!

mnemonic_image.alt: Hot pepper character with sweat drops, closed eyes, arms spread out, and open mouth breathing flames. Radical overlays its body.

name: Comb
mnemonic: Look at all those little things sticking out. You could easily use it tocombyour hair.

name: Wife
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanswife.

name: Saw
mnemonic: You're constructing a table. On the table is a drop of blood, which is your blood. This is from cutting yourself on thesawthat you're using to make the table. Imagine yourself cutting yourself with the saw by accident. Ouch!

name: Clown
mnemonic:
Aclownface, with the funny hat at the top, the silly eyes in the middle, and the big laughing mouth at the bottom. This thing is pretty cute, unlike a lot of clowns…
You could also see this as the stand radical on top of the mouth radical, since standing on their mouth is the kind of weird trick a clown would do.

mnemonic_image.alt: Clown face made of stand radical on top, mouth radical below. Stand radical overlays clown’s hat, eyes, and nose. Mouth radical overlays its mouth.

name: Car
mnemonic: Doesn't this look like a top-down view of the frame of acar? There are the axles at the top and bottom, and the body in the middle between them. That's why this is the car radical.

mnemonic_image.alt: Overhead view of transparent car, showing two horizontal axles with wheels, a four quadrant square frame between them, and a vertical bar overlaying them down the middle, to match the radical lines.

name: Scroll
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansscroll.

name: Again
mnemonic: You've got some legs and fins under the ground. But see that little thing sticking out? That’s there because the legs and fins keep poking outagainand again. They keep poking out of the ground, and you have to shove them back in. Again and again.

name: Slide
mnemonic: Close your eyes and imagine you're a kid again. Now open them and... look! It's aslide! Imagine little you sliding down this slide over and over, having a great time. Imagination + emotion makes for good memorization!

mnemonic_image.alt: Very steep slide that curves down to the left, outlining the radical. A child is sliding down it.

name: Dawn
mnemonic: The sun is coming up out of the ground, making this radicaldawn. Of course, don't confuse this with dusk! You can do that by thinking that the sun is an optimistic and bright thing, so it tends to come up, not go down. (Also, Japan is the Land of the Rising Sun. I mean come on!)

name: Light
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanslight.

name: Rocket
mnemonic: See how there’s a lid on top of the treasure chest? That’s because the whole thing is arocketwhich contains all the necessary items (treasures) to live in outer space. The bottom part of the radical shows you that this is a top secret project, though, so keep this private in your own head.

name: Director
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansdirector.

name: Bamboo
mnemonic: See how tall the stalks are with little bushy things at the top? It kind of looks likebamboo, if you use your imagination.

mnemonic_image.alt: Two stalks of bamboo with leaves on top. The right stalk curls to the left at the bottom. The bamboo radical overlays the two stalks, including leaves.

name: Crab Trap
mnemonic: This radical looks like a small animal (匹) has a crab (其) sticking out of it. Often when a crab is eating a small animal, that small animal was put inside a crab trap to catch the crab, luring it in with the small animal. That's why this radical iscrab trap.

name: Sky
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanssky.

name: Not
mnemonic: This looks like a regular arrow, but it'snot. Let's call it the "not arrow." It cannotmove forward, because it's been stopped by some kind of line above it. Every arrow wants to fly, but this one isnotgoing anywhere. Look at it, being all negated like that. Well, that's just what this radical does. Itnotsthings.

mnemonic_image.alt: Horizontal line above an up arrow. The not radical overlays the line and arrow.

name: Nothing
mnemonic: There are a bunch of cages boiling. But you look inside the cages and there... there'snothing. You boiled whatever was in there down to nothing!

name: Cat Pirate
mnemonic: See the CP in this radical? It stands forCat Pirate. Meoaarrrr.

name: Spikes
mnemonic: On the ground there are a bunch ofspikescoming out. You wouldn't want to step on those now, would you?

mnemonic_image.alt: Four spikes protruding from the ground. Two tall and straight spikes in the center, with shorter diagonal spikes on either side. The radical overlays the spikes and horizontal ground line.

name: Middle
mnemonic: This is a stick going through themiddleof a mouth. What kind of mouth? Mouth of a cylinder, mouth of a box, a human mouth — whatever kind you want to imagine, as long as the stick is going through the middle of it, since this is the radical for "middle."

mnemonic_image.alt: A stick passing vertically through the middle of a cylinder. The shape matches the overlay of the radical, which is made up of the stick radical and the mouth radical.

name: Forehead
mnemonic:
Sure, thisforeheadis a bit square, but that's because it's the top part of the head (冂) radical. This is just the forehead part of that! You can even imagine this as the forehead of Frankenstein's monster, since his forehead was pretty square too.
Also, don't confuse this for a roof. You know this is a forehead and not a roof because this doesn't have a cute little chimney sticking out of the top. Foreheads definitely don't have chimneys.

mnemonic_image.alt: Top half of a bald, square head, showing only eyebrows, eyes, nose, and ears. The forehead radical overlays the top and sides of the head.

name: Cleat
mnemonic: There's the bottom of a shoe with spikes coming out of it. Only one kind of shoe is like this, and that's acleat. You know, like those studded shoes athletes wear. Soccer cleats, baseball cleats, running cleats… You knew they were called cleats, right?

mnemonic_image.alt: Cleat or spiked shoe. Radical overlays horizontal length of shoe and three short spikes underneath.

name: Mysterious
mnemonic: What's under this lid that smells like poop? I don't know! Howmysterious.

name: Criminal
mnemonic: You think you see some legs behind those bars. Who gets put behind bars? Onlycriminals. This criminal is pretty tall, since you only see his legs behind there.

name: City
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanscity.
In case you don't remember the kanji's meaning mnemonic, here's a refresher:
You see a manholelidand atowel, both with the name of acityon them. Decorative manhole lids and souvenir towels — two things cities love to slap their names on, especially in Japan.

mnemonic_image.alt: Manhole cover above a folded towel. Towel and manhole cover have city crest printed on them. Lid and towel radicals overlay.

name: Landslide
mnemonic: If you kick a cliff twice you'll start alandslide! Oh no!

mnemonic_image.alt: Cliff with trees tumbling down it in a landslide. Under it, close up of a foot kicking a rock. Radical overlays the cliff, foot, and cracked rock.

name: Axe
mnemonic: This is the radical foraxe, since it looks like one. The two horizontal strokes are the head, the long left line is the whole edge of its blade, and the vertical line in the middle is its short handle. Kind of a strange axe, I admit, but an axe is an axe.

mnemonic_image.alt: Axe with short handle and large head, its long edge on the left. Radical lines trace the flat head surface, long left curve of the blade, and a T shape where handle connects to axe base.

name: Proclaim
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansproclaim.

name: Shellfish
mnemonic: This radical looks like ashellfish. What looks like the eye radical is its long spiral shell. The bottom part that looks like fins is its little legs poking out, helping the shellfish move around.

mnemonic_image.alt: Tall conical shell set upright, with two thin legs sticking out the bottom to the left and right. The eye radical overlays the shell, and the fin radical overlays the legs, combining to form the shellfish radical.

name: Warehouse
mnemonic: You put your hat on the ground and a flag in your mouth. You're letting the world know that they can use your mouth as awarehouse. Your gullet is open for storage business. Need to store some ice cream? Please use my mouth warehouse. ;D ;D ;D

name: Two
mnemonic: One line plus another line equalstwolines. This radical represents the number two. Pretty simple, right? Can you guess what three looks like? I bet you can...

mnemonic_image.alt: Two horizontal lines, a short one above a longer one, matching the radical shape. The lines are numbered to emphasize there are two of them.

name: Spear
mnemonic: Your mama is carrying some kind of elaborate weapon. You look closely and see that it's aspear. The pointy end is to the right, and there are some decorations hanging off it. It's a very fancy spear, and you wonder where your mama got it.

name: Toe
mnemonic: This radical kind of looks like atoe. See the one weird toe coming off the side of it? This also looks like the katakana characterト(to), which sounds like the word "toe." So whenever you seeト, just think toe.

mnemonic_image.alt: A foot, toes pointed downward along the radical's vertical line, with a massive big toe growing as a diagonal line out of its right side.

name: Early
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansearly.

name: Circumference
mnemonic: You take your head and pack clay dirt around it to just above your mouth. You need thecircumferenceof your head for your helmet maker, and sending them a clay dirt mold of your head will just do the trick. That way they'll know your head's exact circumference!

mnemonic_image.alt: Head wearing a clay helmet with crack in shape of dirt radical. Helmet covers forehead to nose, leaving mouth exposed. Radical lines overlay head, crack, and mouth.

name: Capital
mnemonic:
This looks like the kind of building you'd find in a Japanesecapital. See the ornate roof and the stone foundation flaring out underneath, like a castle? The emperor lives in there. And wherever the emperor lives automatically becomes the capital city. That's why this radical is capital.
Alternatively, you can use the radical parts and imagine a giant lid on the pot that will feed the mouths of all the small people in the capital.

mnemonic_image.alt: Ornate building with stone foundation and steps, representing the capital. Radical overlays roof, building, steps, and foundation.

name: Giant
mnemonic: If you were to look at agiantfrom above, this is what you would see. Do you see the head and two arms? The giant is facing towards the right.

name: Member
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansmember.

name: Neck
mnemonic: This is the radical forneck. Look, you can see all the vertebrae stacked up, and the little ligaments that connect it to the base of the skull! That's why this is the radical for neck.

mnemonic_image.alt: Back of head and neck with spinal column inside. Radical overlays bones of spine.

name: Control
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanscontrol.

name: Lineage
mnemonic: A thread goes through the ground. It traces yourlineage. You follow the thread all the way back through many generations, to find out your lineage involves Genghis Khan. Feel the thread and the dirt in your hand and actually trace the lineage.

name: Ear
mnemonic:
This is theearradical, since it looks like an ear. As much as a radical can, anyway. Those two middle lines are the ridges that guide the sound into your ear, and the lines that stick out to the right are where the ear attaches to your head.
If you think about it, ears are just eyes that see sound. Whoa, dude… That explains the eye (目) and ear (耳) radical resemblance. Just remember this one is "ear" because ears stick out, just like the lines sticking out of the side of this radical.

mnemonic_image.alt: Human ear. Rectangular radical overlays the ear, plus two middle ridges of the ear hole. Top and bottom horizontal lines stick out on both sides. Right vertical line extends below the ear.

name: Simple
mnemonic: This the radical forsimple. Why? Because it looks like a simple little stick figure drawing! Just a big head on top with a few hairs, and a stick figure body. What could be more simple?

mnemonic_image.alt: Simple stick figure with three hairs on its head, simple expression, and two arms. Radical overlays hairs, face and head, and arms and body.

name: Odd
mnemonic: A big lip ring is a prettyoddthing to have. If it's big, it'll stretch your lip out, which is odd too.

name: Bone
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansbone.

name: Bookshelf
mnemonic: This looks like a bunch of books on a shelf. It's abookshelf!

name: Clothes
mnemonic:
You just have to know what’s under these locked lids, so you kick them until they break open to reveal a whole bunch of…clothes. “Wow, free clothes!” you think, just as airport security arrive to take you away.
The clothes radical also looks a little like clothes hanging on a clothes hanger, right?

name: Origin
mnemonic: You have two lines with legs below them. And what is that bit above the legs? Well, it's where you came from — yourorigin. Yep, between two legs is where you originated, no matter how you look at it.

mnemonic_image.alt: Sign saying origin in capital letters, two bare legs protruding under it. The radical overlays the top and bottom edges of the sign, and the two leg lines.

name: Heavy
mnemonic: This is theheavyradical. See the square fist in the center, grasping the handle of a dumbbell that has two heavy plates on the top and bottom? The radical just looks like it would be heavy, you know?

mnemonic_image.alt: Fist holding dumbbell vertically. Vertical line along dumbbell grip. Two horizontal lines overlay each weight at top and bottom. Rice paddy radical overlays fist.

name: Preserve
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanspreserve.

name: Paragraph
mnemonic: You're locking the things that come out of your mouth in prison. The prison of paper and rules, that is. These words turn into well-formedparagraphs.

name: Elephant
mnemonic: This is anelephant— or at least, a wannabe elephant. Look closely. It's actually a family of pigs, and the mama is wearing an elephant mask on her head for some reason. See the big ears and trunk on top? She wants to be an elephant so badly that she dressed up like one.

mnemonic_image.alt: Mama pig with nursing piglets. Mama wears elephant mask with trunk curving up to your left. Pig radical overlays pig. Sun and prison radicals overlay mask and trunk.

name: Comfort
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanscomfort.

name: Eye
mnemonic: See the iris in the middle of the eyeball? Remember that there are no round things in kanji, so square things take their place. That makes this a pretty realistic, squareeye. You just have to squint with your real eyes a bit.

mnemonic_image.alt: A human eye. To match the vertical rectangular shape of the radical, the eye is rotated on its side, its narrow ends at the top and bottom, with a rectangular pupil in the middle.

name: Rice Paddy
mnemonic: In Japan rice paddies are made up of square fields with irrigation lines going between them. See the four rice paddies with water flowing between and around them? That's why this radical isrice paddy.

mnemonic_image.alt: Overhead view of four square rice paddies, with water flowing around their perimeters, outlining the square shape of the radical.

name: Reality
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansreality.

name: Ice
mnemonic: Remember the radical for drop (of liquid)? Looks like it's shattered into two pieces here, which means it must beicenow. You know, since a drop could only break in two after turning into ice.

mnemonic_image.alt: Length of ice broken in two. The two pieces are diagonal lines, the shorter one on top. Their broken ends on the right side tilt inward toward each other to match the radical.

name: Line Up
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansline up.

name: Football
mnemonic: Your friend is on the ground and you step on him with your cleat. There is no friendship here. This is a true sport you're playing. This isfootball.

name: Lion
mnemonic: This L-shaped radical is thelionradical, because "L" is for "Lion." It also looks like a lion's mouth being opened really, really wide. Imagine a lion opening its mouth to yawn. It looks like this radical!

mnemonic_image.alt: Lion facing right, mouth open in L-shape. L-shaped radical overlays the mouth.

name: Blame
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansblame.

name: Tongue
mnemonic:
This is thetongueradical. See that sturdy slide holding a thousand people above a mouth? An open mouth can't support that much weight, but a strong tongue can — it's the muscle of the mouth, after all.
Alternatively, you can think of this as something sticking out of a mouth with thousands of tiny taste buds on it. It's your tongue!

mnemonic_image.alt: Mouth below wooden construct holding up a slide. Tongue from mouth wraps upward around wooden beam. People slide down. Radical lines overlay mouth and slide.

name: Flag
mnemonic: See theflagin this radical? There's a pole with a flag on the end of it, blowing in the wind. Basically, this radical looks just like a flag.

mnemonic_image.alt: Slightly curved flagpole on the left, with a thin rectangular flag on it blowing to the right, all outlined by the radical overlay.

name: White
mnemonic: Add a drop of the sun to something and it will turn itwhite. The sun is really strong, so even a single drop will burn anything white. Why do you think so many beaches are white? Even the drops of sunblock you use to stop the sun's rays is white. So when you think of sun drops, think white.

mnemonic_image.alt: A drop on top of the sun, which has a thin cloud passing across its middle. The white radical, consisting of the drop radical and the sun radical, overlays the art. The drop radical is tilted on its right side.

name: Wolverine
mnemonic: You knowWolverinefrom the X-Men? He has three claws that come out of his hand whenever he needs to fight, not at all unlike the radical you see here.

mnemonic_image.alt: Three horizontal lines joined at their right ends by a vertical line, like a backwards E, forming the wolverine radical, drawn as three blades connected to the knuckles of a fist.

name: Creeper
mnemonic: Do you see the little mustache on top of the mouth? It's one of those creepy mustaches... a John Waters sort of deal. That's why this radical is calledcreeper. (It also bears some resemblance to a certain hissing green thing's head but... well, you remember it how you want.)

name: District
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansdistrict.

name: Gambler
mnemonic: Thegamblerholds a cross as he plays blackjack. He stands on his two legs expectantly, hoping he hits the big one. He just put all his money down. If he doesn't win this one the gambler loses everything, including the two legs he's standing on.

name: Tooth
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanstooth.

name: Scooter
mnemonic: This radical is ascooter. See the handlebars and the little light? And there's a platform at the bottom you can stand or sit on (if it's one of those nice motorized scooters).

mnemonic_image.alt: Scooter facing left, handlebars turned toward viewer so the radical line over them is diagonal. Remaining lines overlay bottom half of the neck, a light protruding from it, front wheel fork, and deck.

name: Gate
mnemonic: This radical already looks like agate, right? A high gate with pillars on either side and two small gate doors, way up at the top for some reason. Worst gate ever in terms of security, but definitely still a gate.

mnemonic_image.alt: Two pillars with gate doors attached on top half only. Radical lines overlay pillars and doors.

name: Sound
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanssound. You can even see someone standing at a kind of square table here. It's a DJ at the turntables! Imagine them spinning records and scratching out all kinds of cool sounds.
You could also remember this with the kanji mnemonic we gave you. Here's the gist of it: If you stand on the sun, you'll hear a very loud sizzling sound.

mnemonic_image.alt: DJ standing at turn tables, which rest on a speaker emitting sound. Stand radical overlays the DJ and tables, sun radical overlays the speaker.

name: Heaven
mnemonic: Remember the guy from the big radical? This is him again, but this time he's so big his head is touchingheaven. He's looking up and has his arms stretched open toward heaven, and his big hair is poking into those heavenly clouds.

mnemonic_image.alt: Big man from the big radical, but with an extra horizontal line on top of his head, representing the clouds of heaven.

name: Water
mnemonic: This is the radical forwater. It's the water radical because it kind of looks like water coming out of a faucet and splashing everywhere. See how it flows off in different directions too? Very water-like! As water-like as a radical can be, anyway…

mnemonic_image.alt: A faucet with water coming out in the shape of the radical, which looks like water flowing in five different directions: a vertical stream, and two smaller streams coming off each side at different angles.

name: Mantis
mnemonic: This radical has slide, head, and insect in it. Which insect will slide your head off in a matter of seconds and then eat it? The fearsome prayingmantis.

name: Mama
mnemonic: This radical is just like the katakana character "ma" (マ). So let's keep things simple and make the radicalmama. It even looks like a mama leaning over and gently tapping her baby to help them fall asleep.

mnemonic_image.alt: Mother over sleeping baby, arm resting on baby. Radical lines overlay mother’s head, shoulder, arm, and baby.

name: Think
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansthink.

name: Poem
mnemonic: The flowery paragraph isn't just regular writing. It's flowery, which makes it apoem.

name: Spirit
mnemonic:
This radical looks like some sort ofspirit. It faces to the left with a big hood over its head, and creepy arms slanting downward at the sides. Can you picture it?
If not, just think of this as the katakana character for "ne." Ne for necromancer, bringing back spirits from the grave! OooooOOoooOoo!

mnemonic_image.alt: Skinny ghoul with shadowy face peeking from under the wide hood of a cloak, facing left. Arms stretched out and down. The spirit radical overlays the ghoul’s hood, back of the head, two arms, and body.

name: Hundred
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanshundred.

name: Noon
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansnoon.

name: Grain
mnemonic:
This is a tree with a drooping slide shape on top. What causes the top of plants to sag? Thegrains. Imagine seeing how the heads of wheat or rice droop when they're ready for harvest. It will look like this radical. Look at all that ripe grain!
This might remind you of米, which has three stalks sprouting upward. You can tell the difference because the top of this one is slanted from the weight of the ripe grain.

mnemonic_image.alt: Stalk of wheat bent at top, two leaves outstretched, two leaves flared diagonally. Radical lines overlay stalk and leaves.

name: Times
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanstimes.

name: Compare
mnemonic: This radical is made up of two slightly different versions of the spoon radical. Look closely at these two spoons.Comparetheir differences, like the different angles in the bends of the spoons. It's like one of those "spot the difference" games where you compare two similar pictures. But this time it's with spoons.

mnemonic_image.alt: Two bent spoons, one bent horizontally, one diagonally. Spoon radicals overlay spoons.

name: Substitute
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanssubstitute.

name: Coffin
mnemonic: See the slide going into the dirt? What appears to be a slide here is actually acoffin, sliding into the dirt to be buried.

mnemonic_image.alt: Dirt radical drawn as a cross in the ground, with the slide radical intersecting the ground line on the right side, drawn as a coffin. The two radicals combine to make the coffin radical.

name: Showy
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansshowy.

name: Dynamite
mnemonic: Doesn't this radical look like one of those old-fashioneddynamiteplunger things that gets pushed to set the fuse? That makes this dynamite!

mnemonic_image.alt: Detonator box labeled TNT, with handle, plunger, and two wires leading to a stack of dynamite. Radical overlays handle, plunger, wires, and box.

name: Horse
mnemonic:
This radical looks like ahorse. See the long, thick neck with the mane flowing to the right? What might look like a wing is actually the horse's four legs and its tail hanging down.
Don't confuse this radical with the bird radical (鳥). They look similar, but this one doesn't have the little feather sticking out of the top of its head!

mnemonic_image.alt: Horse facing your left. Three large locks extend horizontally from mane. Radical lines overlay body, mane, tail, and legs.

name: Form
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansform.

name: Leader
mnemonic: This radical technically means person (like人), but we're going to shift the meaning a little bit. It's kind of like the person radical, but it's taller and skinnier, standing above the others and raising its fist to lead them. That's why this is aleader, not a regular person.

mnemonic_image.alt: Tall, thin man with his fist on your right raised high, other arm outstretched low. Four followers under him, looking up to their leader. The leader radical overlays the man's body and tilted arms.

name: Stamp
mnemonic: This is thestampradical — the inking kind, not the postage kind. Why? Because it looks like a stamp stick! The top parts are thicker on one side so you can get a good grip. It even looks like the letter P — which just happens to be the last letter in "stamp"!

mnemonic_image.alt: Cylindrical stamp that tapers to your left. On top is Crabigator symbol. It stamps same symbol on paper below. Radical lines overlay top and sides.

name: Imperial
mnemonic: Stand up on the moon so you can look down on your countries. The thing with all the lines and borders are the borders of all the countries you rule, for you are animperial.

name: Accept
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansaccept.

name: Key
mnemonic: This is a very oddly shapedkey, but it's a key nonetheless.

mnemonic_image.alt: Key shown vertically, handle at the top. Unusual handle shape extends down diagonally to the left. Key's two teeth protrude rightward. Radical overlays handle base and tail, key body, and teeth.

name: Flood
mnemonic: The three lines that make up the river radical are being pulled to one direction. It's a giant force of water going to the left. It's aflood! RUN!

name: Claw
mnemonic: This looks like aclawof some kind already, making it quite easy!

name: Cow
mnemonic:
This is thecowradical. It kind of looks like the long face of a cow, right? Specifically a boy cow, since you can think of that top horizontal line as its horns. Seeing it yet? It's got a little tuft of hair on its head, and some kind of accessory on the horn to your left, so this is a very stylish cow.
(And yes, you may say a "boy cow" isn't a "cow," but we're still calling this a cow. Please don't write in about it — we don't want any beef.)

mnemonic_image.alt: Cow's face looking at you. It wears a ring around its horn to your left. The cow radical overlays the cow's face.

name: Business
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansbusiness.
Here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: You have spikes growing out of a sheep with fins. Turn this thing into a business! You could totally charge people money to look at it. Sure, you could also donate it to science, but a business-minded person like you knows a business opportunity when you see one. Step right up! Just five dollars for a glance at the rare spiky mer-sheep!

mnemonic_image.alt: Sheep with extra horns and two fins sticking out of its wool. Person beside advertises sheep with megaphone. Radical overlays horns, sheep, and fins.

name: Change
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanschange.

name: Spring
mnemonic: This is thespringradical, because it looks like a new plant shoot has pushed its way up through layers of dirt, snow, and ice to announce the coming of spring. Spring is the season (and the radical) full of new, growing life!

mnemonic_image.alt: Plant shoot peeking above ground. Three horizontal lines overlay soil layers. Two vertical lines flare down through them, overlaying stem and roots.

name: Writing
mnemonic: This looks like a stool with a lid on it, but it's actually a desk forwriting. Do you see it? You can even see the pen sticking up in the middle. Think of all the beautiful writing that's been produced here. Letters, novels, essays — any kind of writing you can think of.

mnemonic_image.alt: Cross legged writing desk, with a quill pen in an ink pot on top. The radical lines overlay the short vertical quill, horizontal desk top, and crossed legs.

name: Pi
mnemonic: Obviously, this looks just like the good ol' 3.14 something-something all people are supposed to learn about. It's the math symbol that has to do with circles...pi!

mnemonic_image.alt: Mathematical symbol for pi. The three radical lines overlay it exactly.

name: Festival
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansfestival.

name: Korea
mnemonic: There are five mouths eating cow atKorean BBQ. Korea is famous for their delicious BBQ, and you need a lot of people to eat all that beef. At least five people. (Get it? Five people!) That's why this radical is Korea.

name: Pig
mnemonic: Here we have the ground radical, with something underneath it. What likes lying in the ground, covered in mud? Apig! Use your imagination and see if you can find the head near the top, the piggy tail at the bottom right, and the little piglets on the left, nestling up to this mama pig.

mnemonic_image.alt: Overhead view of a pig on her right side, legs outstretched with two piglets between. Radical traces the line of her shoulders, front leg, down her belly, back leg, and piglets. Two lines like half an H shape overlay her body.

name: Courage
mnemonic: When a mama stands with a man, it gives himcourage.

name: Book
mnemonic: What's something useful you can get out of a tree? Abook! Just cut that book right out of the tree trunk. If you think about it, every tree contains unlimited book potential. It's just a shame they have to be cut down to make the books…

mnemonic_image.alt: The tree radical with a large book cutting through its trunk, representing the radical’s extra line.

name: Top Hat
mnemonic: This radical looks just like a top hat. That's why it'stop hat!

mnemonic_image.alt: Top hat with large band in middle. Radical lines overlay hat, brim, and outer edges of band.

name: Together
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanstogether. And see how it kind of looks like two people happily sitting together arm-in-arm? These two clearly enjoy doing stuff together. They're together so much they're practically joined at the hip.
Alternatively, think of this as blackjack cards held together by fins. Fish love blackjack because the hands are usually just a few cards, so even fins can hold them together.

mnemonic_image.alt: Two smiling people sitting hip to hip, arms outspread, legs spread at 45 degree angles. Radical overlays their bodies and limbs.

name: Departure
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansdeparture.

name: Black
mnemonic: If you boil a village, everything will turnblack. Just imagine all those roads melting and coating everything in black tar. Picture it! It looks like Pompeii. (Oof, too soon?)

mnemonic_image.alt: Village roads with two burnt houses on streets. Four flames burn under village. Village and boil radicals overlay.

name: Original
mnemonic: See that cliff? The white, small one? That's anoriginalcliff, one of the first cliffs that ever existed. You can always spot original cliffs because they're white and small. More complex cliffs emerged over time, but the original cliffs remained white and small.

name: Hot Pepper
mnemonic: You see something with a flag on it and put it in your mouth. It was spicy! You look at the little flag and it says...hot pepper.

name: Beggar
mnemonic: Doesn't this look like someone on their knees, holding their clasped hands out and begging for something (forgiveness, their life, a promotion, etc.)? That's why this radical is known as thebeggar.

mnemonic_image.alt: Thin man facing right with arms outstretched and pleading look. Radical lines overlay the vertical head and torso, the arms, and the kneeling legs bent in a backward C shape under him.

name: Horns
mnemonic: Can you see thehorns? You could put these horns on anything. Donkeys, people, monkeys, and so on. That's exactly what we'll be doing when we learn kanji that have horns too.

mnemonic_image.alt: Two horns, slightly curved and pointed at the top. They nearly meet at the base, but lean away from each other in a V shape. Two radical lines overlay them.

name: Explosion
mnemonic: See the energy bursting outward? That's anexplosion. Boom!

name: Color
mnemonic: In prison, dreaming in bed is the only way to seecolor. Picture a dark, dank cell with four gray walls. Now imagine the colorful dreamscapes your bed would take you to every night. What a contrast! That's why a prison bed = color.

mnemonic_image.alt: Prison radical above bed radical, with colorful bed spread. A small prisoner above the bed dreams of color.

name: Boil
mnemonic: This radical looks like the fire from the burner of a stove. That's because this is theboilradical. You need to boil a bunch of water over some flames.

mnemonic_image.alt: Boiling pot with four flames underneath. Radical overlays the four flames.

name: Gladiator
mnemonic:
Someone shoved horns onto your husband and said he has to fight for them now. They turned him into agladiator! Now your husband has to fight for their amusement. Are you not entertained?!
P.S. You know this is a gladiator, not a viking, because the horns are on the gladiator's shoulder pads instead of his helmet, and his helmet has a big crest on it.

mnemonic_image.alt: Husband character wearing gladiator helmet, spiked shoulder pads, and skirt. Radical overlays the husband radical and each shoulder spike.

name: Evening
mnemonic: This is the top half of a moon peeking out as it begins to rise. When does that happen? In theevening! Don't confuse this with the moon radical月.夕is for the evening, when the moon's still low enough to be partly covered (by a mountain, for example).

mnemonic_image.alt: Crescent moon rising, its bottom half hidden behind by a mountain. The radical, resembling this broken moon, overlays the image.

name: Servant
mnemonic: Hey, it's that giant you learned before. But... but its arms are chained. They're chained because you caught the giant and now it's yourservant!

name: Twenty
mnemonic: You have十plus十(never mind that the left one is kinda curvy)... What do you get when you add these two kanji together? You gettwenty.

mnemonic_image.alt: Two cross radicals, their horizontal bars joining to create one line. Vertical line on the left cross flares leftward a little at the bottom. The twenty radical overlays them.

name: Correct
mnemonic:
You're lost, but you've come across a signpost that says "correct" in all directions. "Correct," "correct," "correct," it says. No matter which way you go, it's the correct way! What a relief!
You could also use the mnemonic you learned with the kanji: There is a line on the ground so you stop, making a giant sign pop up that says CORRECT! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing. Good on you.

mnemonic_image.alt: Girl looking at signpost with three CORRECT signs pointing in different directions. Radical overlays girl, signpost and signs, and ground line.

name: Escalator
mnemonic: Remember the stairs (乃) radical? This is a lot like that, but it has another stroke to motorize it. The extra bit makes the stairs move by themselves — that's why this is anescalator!

mnemonic_image.alt: Escalator with human figure standing on one step, holding handrail. Radical overlays step and underside curve of handrail.

name: Morning
mnemonic: This is the left side of the kanji朝, so we'll call itmorningtoo.

name: Righteousness
mnemonic: The horns on the king give him an ego. Which in turn gives him a sense ofrighteousness. He shouldn't act all righteous like that, but I suppose it's what kings do. If you had horns and a big ego, you'd probably think you were the epitome of righteousness too.

name: Drop
mnemonic: This little radical is adrop, maybe of water or some other liquid. Notice how it's only one drop? Sometimes radicals and kanji will have more than one drop in them, but don't let that throw you off.

mnemonic_image.alt: A drop of liquid, tapered at the top, tilted on its left side to match the short diagonal line of the radical.

name: Convex
mnemonic: This looks like a box with something sticking out of it. When something is sticking out of something else it'sconvex.

name: Kiss
mnemonic: In winter, your mouth longs for akiss. You know, because your lips get cold and you want someone to warm them up. How do you think that whole mistletoe thing got started? Cold winter mouths, longing for a kiss. So just imagine the top part of this radical as some winter mistletoe (or holly leaves, since that's probably easier), and the bottom part as a kissy mouth.

mnemonic_image.alt: Holly leaves with pursed lips under them. Winter radical overlays holly, mouth radical overlays mouth. They combine to make the kiss radical.

name: Coat Rack
mnemonic: See all the arms sticking out of this radical? Those are for hanging lots of coats and things on, because this is acoat rack. Kind of a weird coat rack, but definitely a coat rack.

mnemonic_image.alt: Coat rack shaped like capital letters T and E combined, with a person radical shape attached to the bottom left corner, where a coat hangs. A hat hangs off right arm of the T. Radical overlays rack, coat, and hat.

name: Well
mnemonic: Think of this radical like a map you're looking down on. There are four streets going through this small town. Right in the middle is the most important thing—thewell. Everyone goes through the four streets to get to the well and get the water they crave.

name: Plate
mnemonic: This is a few plates drying on a rack. They're stacked together in a line. Imagine reaching out and grabbing one of those plates for yourself. And you only need one, so let's call this radicalplate.

mnemonic_image.alt: Three plates upright in a drying rack. The plate radical overlays the bottom of rack, rack spindles up through the sides of the plates, and across the top of the plates.

name: Humble
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji you learned earlier, but the meaning is a little different. It's not just for saying things humbly, it's for beinghumblein general. When you see this radical, think about being humble.
You can kinda see this as someone with their hands pressed together in front of their body, in a very humble posture. Maybe a humble Buddhist monk wearing some big robes? Imagine him all humble there, head bowed, hands pressed together.

mnemonic_image.alt: Humble monk in robes, head bowed, hands together in front of chest in greeting. Radical overlays vertical body line and squarish robed midsection.

name: Become
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansbecome.

name: Employ
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansemploy.

name: Ceremony
mnemonic: This radical looks like a person with a long dress running behind them. That's because they're all dressed up to go to aceremony. You usually have to wear a long dress (or something formal) if you're going to a big ceremony, right? So when you see this radical, think of all the different ceremonies you might have to go to in your life and what you'll need to wear.

mnemonic_image.alt: Woman with ponytail and long dress, arms outstretched, leaning to your left. The dress reaches to her ankles and swoops up in the back. The radical overlays the arms, dress line, and ponytail.

name: Older Brother
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansolder brother.
In case you need a refresher, here's the mnemonic again: Who's someone who's just a mouth with legs? That's your know-it-all older brother, who won't shut up about anything.

mnemonic_image.alt: A big mouth with arms and legs, and a hat that says BIG BRO. Mouth radical above legs radical, combining to make big brother radical.

name: Lid
mnemonic: This looks like something you'd put on a kettle or a pot, right? It even has a little handle to make sure you don't burn yourself. This is some kind oflid.

mnemonic_image.alt: Lid of a pot or kettle, shown from the side as a thin horizontal line, with a short vertical line as its handle in the middle to match the radical.

name: Street
mnemonic: Imagine viewing this one from above — looks like a couple of streets, right? Maybe a three-way intersection at the top there? Well, that's why this is the radical forstreet.

mnemonic_image.alt: Streets intersecting to make the radical shape, which looks like a capital T letter with its bottom curled up to the left.

name: Triceratops
mnemonic: The three horns represent thetriceratops, one of the most awesome dinosaurs ever.

mnemonic_image.alt: Face of a triceratops looking at you, its three horns matching the radical lines: a vertical line in the middle, with two diagonal lines on either side of it.

name: Ego
mnemonic: There's a drunkard holding out his fingers. He's staring at them. Realizing who he is. He's becoming aware of hisego. Now that he's aware of himself, he's probably going to get an inflated ego too. Yuck.

name: Spoon
mnemonic: This radical looks like aspoon! Well, a spoon that's been bent a lot by an angry person or a psychic. Go grab a spoon and try to bend it into this shape. Then hold on to it so you'll never forget that this is the spoon radical!

mnemonic_image.alt: Spoon with its handle at top, so bent in the middle that a fold sticks out, then ending in a wide curve to the right for its bowl. The radical overlays the spoon silhouette.

name: Simultaneous
mnemonic: If you're writing while looking at the moon, you can bet someone else is doing it too. People have a habit of looking at the moonsimultaneously.

name: Wave
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanswave.

name: Thousand
mnemonic: You have a slide supported by a big cross, which makes it so strong it can hold a lot of people at once. How many? ATHOUSAND! Imagine a thousand people going down this slide. You can hear a voice trying to count them as they go: "ONE! TWO! THREE HUNDRED! FIVE HUNDRED!" and so on. Finally the last person slides down and the voice calls out: "A THOUSAND!" You think it's over, but just as that group finishes, in come another thousand…

mnemonic_image.alt: The slide radical on top of the cross radical, making the shape of the thousand radical. Many people slide down the slide to the left, with one holding a banner that says one thousand.

name: Dollar
mnemonic: This is a squiggle with two lines through it. Hmmm doesn't that seem familiar? It should, because it's thedollarsymbol: $. Well, close enough. Just look at this and think, ah yes, a totally normal American dollar.

name: Turtle Shell
mnemonic: Poor turtles. We don't like them here. This is aturtle shell. See the shell with just a tail remaining? It's the only thing we didn't remove off the turtle. It's just a shell with a tail, so basically it's just a turtle shell.

name: Above
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansabove.

name: Village
mnemonic: A rice paddy and some dirt — dirt roads, in fact, because this is avillage. Small villages like this are mostly rice paddies and dirt (roads), you know? You could even think of this as a bird's-eye view of a village.

mnemonic_image.alt: Overhead view of a rice paddy with dirt roads and huts below it. The rice paddy radical sits atop the dirt radical like this, combining to make the village radical.

name: Turtle
mnemonic: There's a turtle shell inside thisturtleradical. You can tell because there's a whole head and tail on this thing, making it a real turtle, not just a turtle shell.

name: Music
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansmusic!曲even looks like a musical score with two notes in the middle. Huh? Real sheet music has more lines, you say? Hey, it's a radical — we're saving ink, not performing Beethoven here.
Alternatively, you could use the kanji mnemonic you learned: There are twenty mouths singing beautiful music together.

mnemonic_image.alt: Sheet music lines intersected by two eighth notes connected at their bottoms. Radical overlays grid like sheet music and high vertical notes.

name: Good
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansgood.
Just in case you don't remember this, here's the kanji meaning mnemonic: Adropof water to arootisgood. It's good for the roots to grow and live and thrive. And what's good for roots is good for our plants and us humans too.

name: Nature
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansnature.

name: Below
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansbelow.

name: Next
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansnext.

name: Call
