mnemonic: If you have a sword in your mouth you need tocallupon someone to help! That thing should not be in there. Call someone over right now! Go ahead, call them! Let’s hope they can get that sword out of your mouth.

name: Lantern
mnemonic: Think of an old-stylelantern. It's in a box-shaped holder lined with rice paper and sits on four legs (you can only see two from this angle though). You can imagine people using these before electricity, right? That's why this radical is a lantern.

mnemonic_image.alt: Wooden lantern on two long legs, the one on your left curved outward. Top and bottom lines of square lamp frame extend beyond lamp. The radical overlays the frame and legs.

name: Clan
mnemonic: Under a cliff, you spot a cross, slightly tilted. The cross is there to mark a famousclanthat once ruled the lands below the cliff. It's a pretty unique cross, so whenever you see it there under the cliff, you'll know it honors the clan who lived there.

mnemonic_image.alt: Cliff over a strange wooden cross with bend on the bottom point. Crabigator in center of cross. Cliff and cross radicals overlay.

name: Hook
mnemonic: This looks like ahook, like the kind a pirate would wear. The flat line shows where the hand was cut off, and the hook is right above, ready to take its place. Yarrrr.

mnemonic_image.alt: A pirate hook curved to your left with skull and crossbones at base. Radical lines overlay base and hook.

name: Long Ago
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanslong ago.

name: Sword
mnemonic: This is theswordradical. Theノpart is the curvy sword, while the rest is a samurai bowing deeply, like 90 degrees, as he holds that sword — probably before a sword fight. By the way, don't confuse this with the power radical (力). See the difference? In the sword radical (刀), theノdoesn't pierce through the bowing samurai. (Lucky for him.)

mnemonic_image.alt: Samurai bowing to the left and holding a sword pointed downward. His bent frame matches the angle on the radical’s right side, while the sword is a vertical line on the left.

name: Greenhouse
mnemonic: Flowers need the sun to get big. To help them grow as big as possible, we put them in thegreenhouse.

name: Coral
mnemonic: In the water is a barb on the ground. It'scoral. Coral may look pretty, but if you slip in the water and step on it, you're gonna get scratched up. That stuff is roooough.

name: Eat
mnemonic: You put on your hat and go outside to kick something white. It's a big white goose and you killed it with your kick. That's because you're going to cook andeatit. Yum!

name: Few
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansfew.
Here's a mnemonic refresher, just in case: You have a small slide. The thing about small slides is thatfewpeople can use them. Not everyone can fit their bum in a small slide — only a few small ones can make it down. That's why this means "few"!

mnemonic_image.alt: Three children on a slide. Behind, others watch and frown. Small radical overlays children, slide radical overlays slide, making the few radical.

name: Cliff
mnemonic: See thecliff? It's facing to the left. What do you think this cliff is jutting out over? Maybe an ocean, or a valley? Cliffs love to jut out over things like that.

mnemonic_image.alt: Rocky cliff topped with grass, sloping downward to your left. The cliff radical overlays the top and left side.

name: Pirate
mnemonic: This kind of looks like big (大), which I think you'll remember you learned by pretending this was a big guy. This big guy, however, has a funny leg... a peg leg. That makes him apirate. Also, his arms are in the "YARRRR" position.

name: Tent
mnemonic: Kind of a strangetent, I'll admit, but one that will protect you from things trying to get in (that's why it has all the spikes). It's the best you can do, considering you're in a cloth tent.

mnemonic_image.alt: Tent facing slightly right, one spike protruding from its left side, two from its right. Radical overlays flat top edge of the tent, its curved left and right front edges, and spikes.

name: Red
mnemonic: A pile of dirt fell on you and now your legs and (scuba) fins are sticking out from under it, turningred. You know, because you've been stuck in the sun so long. Everything's all sunburned and red. Can scuba fins get a sunburn? Yeah, when it's red hot outside. That's why this means "red."

mnemonic_image.alt: Dirt pile with legs sticking out under it, a loose scuba fin on either side. The dirt, legs, and fins radicals overlay these, combining to make the red radical. Sun shines in the upper right.

name: Someone
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanssomeone.

name: Lack
mnemonic: A (modified) prison radical containing a person radical. What does a person experience in prison?Lack. Prison is all about lack — lack of freedom, lack of the comforts of home, lack of privacy, lack of conversation. Yep, the life of a person in prison is defined by lack.

mnemonic_image.alt: Prison radical made of stone over prisoner shaped like person radical. Prison and person radicals overlay.

name: Beans
mnemonic: This radical has a bean (the square in the middle) between the ground and some roots. That bean is going to turn into a plant someday. What will that plant produce? Great bigbeans, like the ones from Jack and the Beanstalk.

mnemonic_image.alt: Bean sprout growing underground. Radical overlays the ground line, large bean under it, and thin roots extending under the bean.

name: Death Star
mnemonic: There is a hat covering the moon and it's holding a knife. Wait, that's no moon. It's a space station! It's theDeath Star! It's pretending to be a moon under that hat. And it's armed! Don't let the Death Star stab your planet to death.

name: Bright
mnemonic: The sun AND the moon are out? With both their light-powers combined, it's incrediblybrightoutside.

mnemonic_image.alt: Sun radical on left, larger moon radical on right. They combine to make the radical for bright, which overlays them.

name: Slice
mnemonic: See the guy? See how he was CUT IN HALF??? That must have been one heckuvasliceto do that to a person.

name: Beforehand
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansbeforehand.
Here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: What does your mama tell you to do in the street? Look before you cross! You gotta do it beforehand, or it could be too late.

mnemonic_image.alt: Mother behind child about to cross street, teaching her to look both ways beforehand. Radical overlays mother, child, and street.

name: Three
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansthree.

name: Wind
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanswind.

name: Products
mnemonic: Three boxes are stacked up on top of each other. These areproductswaiting to be shipped out.

name: Asia
mnemonic: This radical looks like a helicopter on the ground. Or a TIE fighter from above (going to the side). Either way, it's okay because you know where both helicopters and TIE fighters are made:Asia! Most aircraft are made in Asia these days, ya know?

name: Melon
mnemonic: This is amelon. Imagine a melon cut in half, and you're looking at its insides from the side. See those precious private melon parts? You're gonna keep those for yourself, because melons are delicious and not for sharing.

name: Yurt
mnemonic: There's a canopy with a grid-like frame near the top. It's ayurtwith a window! Yurts are those dome-shaped huts nomads use. Once you've set up a canopy with a window frame, you've basically built one. Imagine gazing out that window, kicking back in your yurt. Yurt sweet yurt!

mnemonic_image.alt: A canopy-like yurt with roof, upper window, and left edge visible, and a person lying inside. Radical overlays canopy and window frame.

name: Public
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanspublic.

name: Lovely
mnemonic: I don't know what this thing is, but it'slovely. It has two eyes, a funny mouth, and a scraggly beard. It's lovely, and nothing else, okay? So remember it that way.

name: Past
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanspast.

name: Soul
mnemonic: There are fins floating off of what's left of a fish. This is the fish'ssoul, left over after you ate its body. Make sure you wave goodbye to the souls of the fish you eat. It's respectful.

name: Old
mnemonic: Put a cross in the mouth of a container full of all theoldthings you no longer need. They've all served their purpose but have gotten old, so it's now time to let them rest in peace under the cross. Goodbye, old things!

mnemonic_image.alt: Makeshift cross, representing the cross radical, stuck into a rectangular container, matching the mouth radical. The box is full of miscellaneous old things, including a stuffed toy and a baseball.

name: Head
mnemonic: This is the outline of ahead. A really square head, admittedly, but try to imagine it facing to the right. The left side is the back of the head, and the barb-like part on the right shows the curve of the chin. See the head?

mnemonic_image.alt: Comically square head with a flat nose, facing to the right. The radical overlays only the outline of the head, including the inward curve of the jaw line.

name: Ground
mnemonic: This radical consists of a single, horizontal stroke. What's the biggest, single, horizontal stroke? That's theground. Look at the ground, look at this radical, now look at the ground again. Kind of the same, right?

mnemonic_image.alt: The surface of the ground, corresponding to the horizontal line of the radical.

name: Insect
mnemonic: This looks like the middle radical on top of a sideways leaf. What can you often find sitting on the middle of a leaf? Aninsect. Insects looove sitting right in the middle of leaves. That's why this is the insect radical.

mnemonic_image.alt: Smiling butterfly standing upright on a leaf. The radical aligns with the thin line of its body, rectangular wings, horizontal leaf, and diagonal leaf stem on your right.

name: Same
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanssame.

name: Fortune
mnemonic: Someone has a toe in their mouth. They are a fortune teller telling yourfortune. But for her to do it, she has to take one of your toes and taste it. This better be a good fortune for you to let someone put your foot in their mouth.

mnemonic_image.alt: Foot with outstretched toe standing on lips. Hair draped around toe and mouth. Toe radical and mouth radicals overlay.

name: Stool
mnemonic: This looks just like a foldingstool, am I right?

mnemonic_image.alt: Folding stool with no back, only a flat line for the seat, on two crossed legs to match the radical.

name: Surplus
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanssurplus.

name: Badger
mnemonic: You know the animal radical. This is just like that with a little extra. It's an animal already... which means all you have to do is remember what kind of animal. In this case, it's abadger.

name: Pool
mnemonic: There's a drop of water trapped in a prison. A prison for us to play in! It's apool! The water may not like being in there, but all of us hot people sure do.

name: Library
mnemonic: There's a door over the bookcase. That makes this alibrary!

name: Cottage
mnemonic: If you're wearing a hat and have dirt on your mouth, chances are you're staying in acottage. That's because cottages are usually in the countryside, which means you're likely spending time out in the garden, with a hat on and dirt all over your mouth. You know, your average cottage experience. And hey, this radical even kind of looks like a cottage.

name: Knife
mnemonic: This is aknife. See the sharp edge on the left and the tapered tip on top? And there's a little handle at the bottom for the... well, the handle. Be careful you don't cut yourself on this knife!

mnemonic_image.alt: Wide chef's knife standing vertically, handle down. Two parallel lines overlay left and right sides.

name: House
mnemonic: Under this roof is a pig with her little ones. Your pig, because it's yourhouse! You keep your piggies inside where it's nice and warm. They're all members of your family, so they deserve to live in your house too.

mnemonic_image.alt: Pig nursing two piglets under a roof. Roof and pig radicals overlay pig and roof.

name: Yakuza
mnemonic:
This radical looks like ayakuza. See him facing left, with that threatening jawline and big pompadour hairstyle? Maybe imagine a couple scars on his face too. You know, real yakuza-like.
You could also remember this because it’s the evening radical under the ground radical, and people who do stuff underground in the evening (and night) are definitely yakuza.

mnemonic_image.alt: Profile of yakuza thug looking to your left. Pompadour hairstyle and scar on cheek. Radical lines overlay hair, head, eyes, and scar.

name: Life
mnemonic: Remember the sprout from the dirt radical? This looks like that, but wait a minute… there's some extra growth now! This thing is so full oflife! It's even got a big, slide-shaped leaf growing on the top left. That's why it's the life radical.

mnemonic_image.alt: Plant growing up out of the ground, a leaf on top and two leaves branching out from each side of the main stem. One leaf on the left is diagonal, matching the top left stroke of the radical.

name: Scarecrow
mnemonic: A creeper in a rice paddy? That's just ascarecrow!

name: Small
mnemonic: You see two fins around a barb, but when you look closer, you realize those fins are actually two tiny fish. Think how small these fins (and fish) would have to be to look so much smaller than an already small barb. Talk about small fry… Yeah, that's why this is the radical forsmall.

mnemonic_image.alt: Small barb, with a small fish floating on each side, both positioned with heads tipped toward the barb, as if attracted to it. The radical overlays the vertical barb and diagonal fish.

name: Crab
mnemonic: This looks like the shellfish radical, but a little different. It's the mightycrab! See the eyes and raised pincers at the top, the segmented belly in the middle, and the legs bunched up at the bottom? It takes some imagination, but this spiky shellfish definitely looks like a crab.

mnemonic_image.alt: Crab on its back legs, showing its belly, beady eyes on top of its head and raised claws. Radical overlays eyes, segmented belly, and two bottom legs.

name: Shrimp
mnemonic: This radical has a little head and some shrimpy legs sticking out of it. That's because it's ashrimp!

name: Angle
mnemonic: When you're in prison, your only task is to count everyanglein your cell. You count the angles of the walls and ceiling over and over again to pass the time. How many angles could there be in a room with four walls? Picture it and try to count those angles now.

mnemonic_image.alt: Prison radical above task radical, with angles of each indicated with angle measurements. Prisoner sits at bottom, counting angles.

name: Master
mnemonic: The king is hovering a drop of water over his head. He's acquired the ability to manipulate water at will, making him themasterof all water! If you think about how all life depends on water, that really makes him the master of everything…

mnemonic_image.alt: Drop of water hovering over a king, sat on a throne with hands raised.  The drop radical overlays the drop, and the king radical overlays the  throne, combining to make the master radical.

name: Good Luck
mnemonic: This is the samurai radical on top of the mouth radical. If you get to hear what a samurai says, you'll have reallygood luck. Samurai are pretty hard to find nowadays, which is probably why my luck has been so bad...

name: Flowers
mnemonic:
See the little things sticking out of the ground? Those little things are pretty littleflowers.
You could also see this as a little flower crown, especially since this radical almost always appears at the top of a kanji.

mnemonic_image.alt: Ground with two flowers, both with straight roots beneath soil and stems above ground. Radical overlays ground line, roots, and flower stems.

name: Commander
mnemonic: Who wears cleats and takes your measurements for so long that icicles start forming on your body? Yourcommander. The commander is very, very particular. And everyone knows the commander has to get everything exactly right. So taking your measurements takes SO long that icicles grow out of your nose. But that's okay. You have to impress your new commander, darn it!

name: Nurse
mnemonic: This radical is made up of blackjack and clothes with the six kanji on top. If you see six people playing blackjack and wearing the same clothes you should know that they're allnurses. Nurses play blackjack together to cool down between shifts and they usually don't have time to change out of their uniforms. That's why this radical is nurse.

name: Snake
mnemonic:
This is thesnakeradical. See the head at the top with its long skinny body stretching down from it?
Don't confuse this with己(oneself) — the snake has an extra line behind its head to connect to the rest of its body.

mnemonic_image.alt: Snake with large head curled up in C shape. Radical lines overlay head and body.

name: Temple
mnemonic: This radical looks kind of like atemple, don't you think? With all the layers and stuff? Just picture the top part as a roof, and the drop-looking bit at the bottom as a giant temple bell, with a monk standing beside it and ringing it with a large wooden beam. You see this kinda thing every day at a temple.

mnemonic_image.alt: Temple roof over bell on left and monk hitting bell with pole on right. Dirt radical overlays roof. Radical lines overlay bell, pole, and monk.

name: Net
mnemonic: This is anet, spread out over the water. Imagine all the fish you can catch in this net!

mnemonic_image.alt: Wide rectangular net in three segments. Crabs and fish caught in net. Radical lines overlay edges of net and segments.

name: West
mnemonic:
You have the legs of a bird with wings outspread, landing in the mouth of her nest to rest. And when does she go back to rest? When the sun sets in thewest! Imagine all the birds flying home as the sun sets. That's why this radical means west.
You could also see this as pi coming out of a mouth. Why would a mouth be talking about pi? Probably to figure out the curvature of the sun's path as it moves across the sky — to the west, always to the west!

mnemonic_image.alt: Pi radical with its legs half inside the mouth radical under it. They combine to make the west radical, drawn here as a wide, flat bird with its legs in a nest.

name: Boat
mnemonic: This looks like aboatcoming toward you in the water. See the sail billowing on top and the reflection on the water? Yep, that's a boat. The boatiest boat that ever boated.

mnemonic_image.alt: Boat with sail on deep ocean. Square radical with two drops overlays boat. Radical lines of surface of water and three vertical lines below surface.

name: Bar
mnemonic: There are two drunkards here. That makes this radical abar. Where else are you gonna drink?

name: Demon
mnemonic: This is ademon. Can you see him? He has a crazy face and some tentacles holding something demonic. Try to figure out how to see a demon. But don't see him too good, cause then he'll come out of your computer and eat you.

name: Walk
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanswalk.

name: Grass
mnemonic: Don't confuse this with triceratops.Grassis closer together, and a little bushier, like this. It's also more random and squished down in parts. If you see a bush of lines like this, it's probably going to be grass.

name: Mohawk
mnemonic: You have something old on your head that's standing up. What is this thing? An awesomemohawk. You've had it so long it's looking pretty old... but still awesome.

name: Brush
mnemonic: This radical kind of looks like abrush. The top part is a hand holding the brush handle, and the bottom part is the bristly tip.

mnemonic_image.alt: Writing brush in a hand. Vertical line overlays handle and brush. Five horizontal lines cross it. Three overlay the hand, two overlay the brush below. The top three are linked on right by a short vertical line.

name: Bully
mnemonic: He's a creeper and he's Four-T (forty). If someone like this creeps on you, they're just abully. When you get to forty you aren't supposed to creep on people anymore. You bully. You jerk.

name: Splinter
mnemonic: Although a little bit modified, there is a turtle shell that's on a mustache with this radical. The only thing with a mustache that hangs around turtles is Splinter, the giant rat from Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. So this radical isSplinter(the giant rat).

name: Orders
mnemonic:
This radical meansorders, because it looks like Napoleon with his big bicorne hat, giving orders. You move, or his orders move you.
See how his body looks like the stamp radical (卩)? If it helps, you can think of Napoleon's written orders as bearing his stamp of approval. All official orders need the stamp of that guy under the big hat, you know?

mnemonic_image.alt: Napoleon in bicorne hat, holding a paper and pointing left as if giving orders. Radical overlays hat, brow, and upper body.

name: Kick
mnemonic: This looks like a stick-figure foot on the left kicking at something, which makes it the radical forkick. See the shin and foot swinging up for the kick? You can think of that part on the right as the edge of a ball that's about to be kicked.

mnemonic_image.alt: Leg and shoe facing your right, speeding toward a ball with seam and stitches. Kick radical overlays vertical shin, flat bottom of shoe, and bottom edge and seam of ball.

name: Blade
mnemonic: You have a sword that has a drop of something on it. That drop is a drop of blood. Sure, a sword will cut someone to spill some blood, but all you really need is any kind ofbladeto cut someone. Sword, knife, whatever, as long as it's a blade.

name: Big
mnemonic: This radical looks just like a stick figure—more specifically, a reallybigguy with his arms stretched out nice and big. When you see this radical, just think big, because this guy is really BIG!

mnemonic_image.alt: Big guy with long arms and legs stretched out wide. Short head above horizontal arms, and two long legs flaring out underneath to match the radical.

name: Teacher
mnemonic: Who's in the coffin next to that child? It's histeacher. Teachers are pretty much dead around 3 p.m. every day, and it's the kids in their class who wear them down. It ain't easy being a teacher, you know.

mnemonic_image.alt: Kid standing with arms outstretched in front of corpse-filled coffin and cross headstone. Coffin radical overlays headstone and coffin. Child radical overlays child.

name: Previous
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansprevious.

name: Catapult
mnemonic: See the rock in thecatapult? It even has little legs to hold it steady so it can catapult better.

name: Arrow
mnemonic: This is a gun on top of a big person. The gun is big too, obviously. Why is this big guy's gun so big? Because it shootsarrows! Bullets are pretty small, so the guns that shoot them can be any size. But you need a big gun if you want to shoot a big arrow, right? That's why this is the radical for arrow.

mnemonic_image.alt: The gun radical set on top of the guy from the big radical. The gun has an arrow sticking out of its barrel.

name: Sake
mnemonic: This radical looks like a big, weird caterpillar bug thing. But, for the sake of everyone's sanity, we'll just call itsake, okay? Keep in mind, we mean sake as in "for the sake of X," not as in the alcoholic beverage!

name: Sick
mnemonic: This is the canopy radical with ice running down the back. If you hang out in a cold canopy like this you'll definitely getsick. Imagine being sick and alone inside a cold canopy. Brrrr, oh no... ACHOO!

mnemonic_image.alt: Canopy with broken icicle on its left side, and sick person with blanket, thermometer, and cold compress inside. Radical overlays canopy and ice.

name: Mustache
mnemonic: See themustachegoing around the mouth? Man, I wish I could grow a sweet mustache like this. (Sure, the mustache looks a lot like the head radical here, but just imagine it as a mustache this time!)

mnemonic_image.alt: Horseshoe mustache around lips in O shape. Side of mustache on your right hooks inward. Radical traces mustache, with mouth radical overlaying the lips.

name: Blackjack
mnemonic: You have the radical twenty and the kanji one. Put those together and you get 21. What's another name for 21? That'sblackjack.

mnemonic_image.alt: Two crosses connected side by side, standing on one line. Each is labeled 10, while the line under them is labeled 1. Radical overlays the lines.

name: Geoduck
mnemonic: A leaf-shaped protrusion coming out of a shellfish. What is it? The mysteriousgeoduck! The geoduck is a giant clam so big that most of it grows outside its shell. If you've never seen a geoduck, look it up now. You'll never be able to unsee it.

mnemonic_image.alt: Shell with clam body squeezing out of it on three sides, long neck bending at the top. Geoduck radical overlays neck and shell.

name: Fault
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansfault.
Just in case you don't remember the kanji's meaning mnemonic, here's the gist: That slide is your husband's onlyfault. He spends all day sliding down it like a madman, which is why his hair sticks straight up on top. Maybe that's another fault… It's also a way to remember this is失(fault), not矢(arrow).

mnemonic_image.alt: Slide in background, with ecstatic husband figure lying on ground in foreground. Fault radical overlays slide, ground line, and husband.

name: Stick
mnemonic: This is astick, sticking straight up. It even looks like a stick.

mnemonic_image.alt: A thin wooden stick shown vertically, matching the single straight line of the radical.

name: Mountain
mnemonic: This is amountain. See the big peak in the middle and the smaller ones on either side? This totally looks like a mountain.

mnemonic_image.alt: Mountain with three peaks shown as three vertical lines, middle one longer than the others. The peaks are joined at the base by the horizontal line of the radical.

name: Door
mnemonic: This one looks like a flag, but don't be fooled — it's got a line over the top of it, kind of like a door frame. That makes this a littledoor. Specifically a swinging door, with the vertical line on the left being its door hinge. Kind of a weird door, it's true, but you can see it, right?

mnemonic_image.alt: Small swinging saloon door. The radical outlines the door and the frame above it and to its left.

name: Oneself
mnemonic: This kinda looks like a head with an arm under it pointing up at itself. That's why this radical meansoneself. One points to oneself when one wants to… indicate oneself…

mnemonic_image.alt: Profile of person facing your right, arm curved under face, fingering point at themself. Radical lines overlay top of head, face, chin, and arm.

name: Barracks
mnemonic: You stick an umbrella with a big slide on it into the mountainside to make yourbarracks. You're going to use these barracks to teach soldiers how to slide slides and hide from bad weather. It's ingenious!

name: Winter
mnemonic:
This is the radical forwinter. It looks like a skier going downhill (to the left), with their skis out in front and their poles out behind them. And when do people ski? In winter!
You could also remember this as looking like the evening radical but with an extra long stroke, since the evenings are long in winter. It gets dark early in winter, you know?

mnemonic_image.alt: Skier crouched as they race leftwards downhill, scarf fluttering behind them. Under their tucked legs, their skis and ski poles intersect to make an angle that flares open downwards like the radical.

name: Before
mnemonic: The meaning of this radical is the same as the alternative kanji meaning. It meansbefore.

name: East
mnemonic: Behind that tree the sun is rising in theeast. The sun always rises in the east, so if you head that way, past the tree, you'll be going east too.

mnemonic_image.alt: Tall fir tree with large sun rising behind it. East radical overlays the sun, tree trunk, and branches.

name: Bear
mnemonic: This is the radical forbear, because it looks like the letter B — B for bear! You know this one is "bear" and not "building" because it's all boxy, like a stocky, chunky bear who's all fat and ready to hibernate.

mnemonic_image.alt: A boxy capital letter B drawn as a cute bear. Radical overlays the letter’s lines.

name: Renew
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansrenew.

name: Friend
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansfriend.

name: Thread
mnemonic: In some poop you find something small. You lean in, carefully pull it out, and realize it's athread. What's that doing there? Well, it came from a cat, and cats love to eat thread when you aren't looking. And floss and hoodie strings and mouse tails… But this time, just thread.

mnemonic_image.alt: The smiling poo from the poop radical. Attached under it is the small radical, overlaying a curly M shaped thread. Together they make the thread radical.

name: Womb
mnemonic: Legs appear between two lumps of dirt. This is the earth's version of awomb. Imagine a tiny baby growing under the ground and then sprouting out, legs first, into the world. Imagine being inside this dirt womb. It's warm and damp. You feel safe.

name: Peace
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanspeace.

name: Cage
mnemonic: This radical is acagebecause it's covered on all sides but one (the one open side is where the cage door or gate is). There's nothing inside this cage because there's no gate, and whatever was inside has gotten out. I hope it wasn't rabid...

mnemonic_image.alt: A square cage with vertical bars. Radical lines overlay top, left, and bottom.

name: World
mnemonic: Use your imagination to draw a circle outside this shape. The grids from the radical start to look like longitude and latitude lines on a globe, don't they? That's why this is theworld.

mnemonic_image.alt: Globe with radical overlaid as longitude and latitude lines. The radical forms and L shape on the left, intersected near the top by a horizontal line, which is intersected with an angular U shape near its right end.

name: Farming
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansfarming.

name: Box
mnemonic: Thisboxis open. There could be any number of things inside, but for now all you need to know is the meaning of this radical, which is box.

mnemonic_image.alt: Box filled with fruit, open on top. Radical lines overlay bottom and sides.

name: Valley
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansvalley.

name: Mask
mnemonic: This looks kind of like amask, right? It has horns, it has crazy eyes, and it has a big mouth. Nobody would actually look like this, which is why this is just a mask.

name: Body
mnemonic:
This radical is almost the same as the kanji, but it drops the "some" from somebody, making this just abody. Like the physical body you're trapped in right now.
Just in case you don't remember the kanji meaning, here's the mnemonic again: Sure, it’s yourselfwho’s tumbling down theslide… at least that’s how it feels to you. Who are you? What are you? All you know is you’resomebody, but you don’t know who that somebody is.

name: Moon
mnemonic: This is themoonradical. See how it looks like a crescent moon with a couple of little clouds floating by? Try not to mix this up with the evening radical夕— you can see the whole crescent moon this time, so obviously this should be the radical for moon!

mnemonic_image.alt: A crescent moon with two thin clouds passing across its upper half, roughly matching the radical shape.

name: North
mnemonic: You only have some ice and a stick for your spoon, because you're way up north. At the top of the world, there's only ice to eat, and — if you're lucky — a bit of stick for flavor. That's thenorthfor you.

mnemonic_image.alt: Upright stick with two icicles sticking out to your left. Next to it a bent spoon. They stand at North Pole. Radical lines overlay ice, stick and spoon.

name: Fire
mnemonic:
This is the radical forfire. It's got three little flames on top and even a couple logs underneath.
But if it helps you can also focus on the person radical here. See it? It's got things coming off of it... What are those thi— OH MY GOD IT'S FIRE!!! Help, help! Put the fire out! Wait, it's fine… It's just the fire radical.

mnemonic_image.alt: Small fire with three flames showing the top part of the radical, burning atop two logs that lean inward against each other to represent the bottom part of the radical.

name: Drunkard
mnemonic: This is a ceremony radical with a slide radical. Why would a ceremony need a slide? Fordrunkards, of course! People love to drink at ceremonies, and when they've had too much, those drunkards like to go down slides. If your ceremony has a slide, the drunkards will be happy.

mnemonic_image.alt: Woman from ceremony radical, now drunk and going down a slide sideways, arms outstretched. Radical overlays her and the slide.

name: Yellow
mnemonic: Flowers that grow out of the ground of a rice paddy after you bury fins there will growyellow. Why? Because yellow is the color of a fish's soul, so planting flowers over their fins will turn them into a nice, pretty yellow.

name: Roof
mnemonic: This is aroofーa flat roof with a little chimney sticking out. How cute!

mnemonic_image.alt: Flat roof line with a short chimney line sticking up in the middle, plus two short vertical lines coming off the roof's sides to complete the radical shape.

name: Certain
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanscertain.

name: Angel
mnemonic: First of all, there's a cross making up the middle, which automatically makes this a religion-based radical. That cross is the frame of someone's body and the things coming off of it are wings. This is anangel.

mnemonic_image.alt: Angel in robes facing you, arms outstretched, wings below arms. Radical lines overlay arms, body, and wings.

name: Jet
mnemonic: This is like one of thosejets that have the little nose-wings going on too. Imagine you're looking at the jet from the top down, this is what it would look like. It's also why this is the jet radical.

mnemonic_image.alt: Overhead view of jet, small wings near nose, large wings in center, small diagonal wings near tail. Radical lines overlay fuselage and wings.

name: Rake
mnemonic: If you look at it, you can see it's a weird lookingrake.

name: Skin
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansskin.
Here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: You slide down a branch and your skin scrapes right off — ouch! Lucky for you, it was just your old outer layer of skin, and now you've got a fresh shiny layer. Yay for exfoliation! You're not sure what to do with this big, floppy layer of old skin, though…

mnemonic_image.alt: Shiny human figure on right, holding up a layer of shed skin on left. Skin resembles figure but with crossed legs. Radical overlays skin only.

name: Man
mnemonic: A rice paddy needs power, and that power comes from aman. Picture a rice paddy full of thick, wet mud. It's no easy field to work in, but this powerful man will bend over to rake and hoe tirelessly to make sure it thrives. What a man!

mnemonic_image.alt: Four square rice paddy. Below it, a man facing your left bent at the waist and holding a rake outward. The rice paddy radical overlays the rice paddy, and the power radical overlays the man.

name: Wild
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanswild.

name: Wide
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanswide.

name: Circle
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanscircle.
Just in case you don't remember this, here's the kanji meaning mnemonic: What's something withninesides? Just add adropand you'll have something that's almost acircle.

name: Reason
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansreason.

name: Eternity
mnemonic: A drop of water will last for aneternity. Especially if you drop it into an endless stream that never stops flowing. You can see these streams converging from all directions here, flowing for eternity.

mnemonic_image.alt: Drop of water hanging above converging rivers. Drop radical overlays drop, water radical under it overlays rivers, combining to make eternity radical.

name: South
mnemonic: This is the radical forsouth. See how it's pointing south? You can think of the cross on top as a compass rose, and the arrow below (that ¥-looking part) as pointing down south. It's a compass pointing nowhere but south!

mnemonic_image.alt: Compass rose above a compass pointing south. Radical overlays the rose, the top, left, and right edges of the compass, and its needle.

name: Poop
mnemonic: For better or worse, this looks enough like the poop emoji (💩) to make this thepoopradical. Try to remember it for its distinct outline. If it helps you can also note the private radical on the bottom of this one, since you should probably be in private when you poop…

mnemonic_image.alt: Swirly poo with a smiley face on it, reminiscent of the emoji. Two stacked triangular shapes make up the radical overlay.

name: Face
mnemonic: You have a leaf, a mouth, and an eye. Those are all things you'll find on aface! Wait, you don't have a leaf growing out of your face? Huh... well just imagine you have a normal human face with a leaf on there somewhere, ya weirdo.

name: Leather
mnemonic: When I look at this radical, I see the body and (mainly) head of a bull. What are bulls made of? They're made ofleather.

name: Husband
mnemonic:
The radicals ground and big make up this radical. There's a big guy on the ground... who is that big guy? Embarrassingly, it's yourhusband. Feel the shame that he got knocked down on the ground. By what? Who? How? (It doesn't matter.)
Don't confuse this with未(jet), though. See how未has a little tail at the end? That's because jets and other planes have tails, while husbands don't. At least I'd sure hope yours doesn't.

mnemonic_image.alt: Sad man in shape of big radical lying in dirt. Surface of dirt crosses his tall hair. Radical lines overlay ground. Big radical on man.

name: Guy
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansguy.

name: Restaurant
mnemonic: You see a lid on the street with a drawing of a forehead and a mouth on it. Hmm strange. You pick the lid up and reveal... a secret, undergroundrestaurant! The mouth + forehead combo was secret street restaurant code for, "There's good eats down in this here restaurant hole!"

name: Signpost
mnemonic: This is a post with signs on it. And on top is a winter marker, showing that if you go north it's winter up there. The signs say things like "Narnia ↑" and "Meridell ←" and "Bananaland →" so you know it's asignpost.

name: Valuable
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansvaluable.

name: Construction
mnemonic: You know those big steel girders that are used for the frame of big buildings? This is like the end of one of those, and has a very distinct shape, just like this radical. These girders are used in construction, which is why this radical meansconstruction. Funny thing is, you use these girders to put together buildings just like you're going to use this radical to put together kanji!

mnemonic_image.alt: Construction girders in the shape of the radical, which looks like the capital letter H, but rotated 90 degrees.

name: Height
mnemonic: There is a narwhal at the top of this slide. What's it doing? The narwhal is trying to increase itsheight. Picture a narwhal propping itself up on a slide. It's self-conscious of its height. It's trying to prove to all the other narwhals that it should be allowed to play in their narwhal games, even though it's not the same height as them.

name: Talent
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanstalent.

name: Penguin
mnemonic: There are fins wrapped in a towel in winter. Who is drying these fish fins to eat them? Apenguin.

name: Tofu
mnemonic: See the T and F that make up this radical? Those letters stand fortofu, our favorite bean curd blocks.

mnemonic_image.alt: The word tofu written with prominent T and F. Top T line is diagonal, while F leans back leftward against the T. Radical overlays T and F.

name: Dry
mnemonic: This looks like a clothesline pole you woulddryclothes on. It's got two very straight horizontal poles, for maximum drying efficiency. If you were gonna dry your clothes, you'd dry them on this thing.

mnemonic_image.alt: Clothesline pole with two horizontal poles on top of it, matching the radical shape. The top pole is a little shorter than the one under it. Laundry hangs off ropes coming out of each horizontal pole.

name: Canopy
mnemonic: This is acanopy. See the cloth draping down and the little point at the middle holding it up? You could sit under here and enjoy a bright summer day without getting any sun!

mnemonic_image.alt: Outdoor canopy with a pointed roof, matching the radical's top part, with fabric hanging down on the left side for shade, shown as a gently curving vertical line to match the radical.

name: Fat
mnemonic: This looks like the guy from the big radical, but he's got something extra on his belly. That's his exposed belly button, because he's a sumo wrestler now: big andfat. In sumo, more fat means more power, so imagine he's been training to get as strong and fat as possible.

mnemonic_image.alt: Sumo wrestler with arms outstretched and prominent belly button. Big radical overlays his arms and body, drop radical overlays his belly button.

name: Inside
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansinside.

name: Leaf
mnemonic: There's a leaf on top and a stem going down out of it, making this theleafradical. It's a pretty wide and flat leaf, so if it helps you can imagine it as a lily pad leaf.

mnemonic_image.alt: A wide, flat leaf viewed from the side, with a long stem hanging under it. The two radical lines overlay the surface of the leaf and the leftward sloping stem.

name: Vines
mnemonic: This radical is made up of twovineshanging down and a branch linking them together. Imagine swinging on these Tarzan style. AaaaAA aAA AAAaaaa!

name: Number
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji, but "number in a series" is too long. Let's shorten it tonumber.

name: Boot
mnemonic: There's something made of leather with some dirt on the bottom of it. It's aboot!

name: Alligator
mnemonic: See the mouth and long, fang-like teeth of thisalligator, which is facing to the right? You wouldn't want to get your hand stuck in there, that's for sure.

mnemonic_image.alt: Smiling alligator head with two large top fangs, one curved inward. The alligator radical lines overlay the head, lower jaw, and two teeth.

name: Energy
mnemonic: This is the radical forenergy. If you imagine a train under this radical, then the lines would be steam bursting out of it, flowing back from the front of the train (on the left) as it goes chugging along. Steam was the best way to generate energy back in the day, you know? That's why this is the radical for energy.

mnemonic_image.alt: Steam train facing left. A large cloud of steam flows up from the stack in a short diagonal line, over the top in three longer horizontal lines, and down the back in a short vertical line to match the radical.

name: Part
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanspart.

name: Run
mnemonic: See the personrunning? Don't confuse this with foot (足), though. The head is just a streak because this person is running so fast.

name: Frostbite
mnemonic: This radical is made of dirt, legs, and winter. If you have to bury your legs in the dirt in winter, it's probably because you gotfrostbite. You had to leave your dead legs behind. :(

name: Stop
mnemonic: There's a stick and a giant toe stuck in the ground. Imagine walking along and seeing these things in your path. What would you do? Most likely come to a completestop. You know, because of the toe. I guess a normal stop sign wasn't good enough, so they also put up this big toe to really get people to stop.

mnemonic_image.alt: Two stop signs, overlaid by two vertical radical lines, with the right line also having a giant toe sticking out horizontally, to the right. Under them a line for the ground to complete the radical shape.

name: Fly
mnemonic: This radical is pretty complicated, but not much looks like this radical, so you're in luck. This looks like a giant flying fortress of some kind. See the propellers on the back as it moves to the left? Just imagine something like this flying through the air. That's why this radical isfly, because it is flying.

name: Long
mnemonic: When a stick figure has hair that drags on the ground and gets kicked all the time, you know that hair's gotta belong. Why is it so looooong?!

mnemonic_image.alt: Stick figure woman facing your right, kicking leg out, five strands of hair over leg. Radical lines overlay woman and hair.

name: Rice
mnemonic: This is the radical forrice. Specifically raw rice, like the grain that grows out of the ground when rice is raw and fresh. When rice is particularly ripe, it'll kind of look like this at the top of the stalks. See the long leaves and the little rice tufts at the top? That's why this radical is "rice."

mnemonic_image.alt: Rice plant. Two leaves stick out to the sides, and two fan out diagonally under them. Three rice shoots left, right, and center above the leaves. The radical overlays the stem, leaves, and rice shoots.

name: Dirt
mnemonic: At first this looks like a cross in the ground, but it's actually something growing in thedirt. It's a little sprout, already rocking three leaves. And it's all thanks to that dirt! When you see this radical, think about how amazing it is that things just, like, grow in the dirt.

mnemonic_image.alt: A sprout with three leaves, growing in the dirt. The middle leaf points straight up, and the other two point straight out to the side to match the radical overlay.

name: One Sided
mnemonic: This looks a bit like a waiter walking toward you with a platter in their hands... but wait. It's only half of a waiter. It's aone sidedwaiter!

name: Hand
mnemonic:
This is thehandradical. If you look at the palm of your right hand, the lines in it probably kinda look like the lines in手. Sure it's not a perfect match, and everyone's got different hands, but basically this radical looks like the lines in your hand.
You could also think of the horizontal lines in手as fingers. That would make for a pretty alien-looking hand, but still a hand… of sorts…

mnemonic_image.alt: An open hand, its palm facing you and its thumb on your right. The lines in the palm match the radical overlay.

name: Shop
mnemonic: We already have a roof radical, so we're going to use the secondary kanji meaning for this radical. It'sshop, remember?

name: Receive
mnemonic: Put a lid on the mouth of a child and what will youreceive? At best, a very unimpressed look from that poor child. If you want to receive nice things, putting lids on children’s mouths isn’t the way to go about it.

name: Black Hole
mnemonic: When you shoot your gun at the sun, it becomes winter. The shot you fired sent the sun into a crazy chain reaction, making it implode in on itself and become ablack hole. Imagine this happening and imagine the shock you'd feel. You shot the sun. You caused this infinite winter (and soon black hole death).

name: Half
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanshalf.

name: Guest
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansguest.

name: Father
mnemonic: This is thefatherradical, since you can see a very fatherly face in it — two droopy eyes at the top, a big nose in the middle, and a mustache flaring out at the bottom. Sort of a generic older gentleman father-type face, isn't it?

mnemonic_image.alt: Man's face with the radical overlaying it. Two lines for closed, droopy eyes. Under them an X shape, showing the tapered nose on top and a mustache on the bottom.

name: Weapon
mnemonic: Stick a table on top of a stool and you end up with a very dangerousweapon. Imagine hitting someone with this thing! Or, even better, imagine making someone sit on it. They'd be crushed mentally and emotionally and whatnot. Now that's a scary weapon.

mnemonic_image.alt: Table wobbling on stool. A distressed person sits on table. Table and stool radicals overlay.

name: Plow
mnemonic: You're sliding some dirt around with a tree you cut down. This contraption you've made is called aplow. Use it to push dirt around!

name: Psychopath
mnemonic: Inside this guy's forehead you have a spoon and a bunch of hair, not to mention whatever that is in the top left. That's the mind of apsychopathright there.

name: Treasure
mnemonic: This radical istreasurebecause "X marks the spot," as they say. Doesn't it look like the X on a pirate treasure map? You want to go find that treasure now, right?!

mnemonic_image.alt: Treasure map with the X shaped radical marking the treasure spot.

name: Dragon
mnemonic: A turtle that stands up isn't a turtle anymore. It's evolved into a monster. What kind of monster? Adragon! Rawwwr.

name: Treasure Chest
mnemonic: There's a treasure radical inside this box. What holds treasures? Atreasure chest.

name: Measurement
mnemonic: Have you ever used one of those triangular rulers? This looks just like one of those, because this is themeasurementradical. Just think of all the angles you could measure with this thing!

mnemonic_image.alt: Triangular ruler with a triangular hole. One small radical line overlays the inside edge of the hole. Overlaying the top and right edges of the ruler, two longer lines that intersect to form two perpendicular right angles.

name: Suit
mnemonic: This is the radical forsuit, like when something suits you. You find a hat on the ground, and when you pick it up, there's a mouth underneath. "It suits you! It suits you!" the mouth says. You try the hat on, and yup — it really suits! It's weird getting fashion advice from a random mouth, but hey, it wasn't wrong.

mnemonic_image.alt: A straw rice hat casting shadow directly under it. Below that, a mouth. Hat, ground, and mouth radicals overlay.

name: Sweet
mnemonic: This radical is the sun with its hair sticking out. Why is the sun's hair sticking out like this? It ate wayyy too manysweetthings causing it to have too much energy, making its hair stand on end. It also kind of looks like a sweet, sweet candy with the wrapper sticking out. Remember it how you'd like.

name: Hat
mnemonic: Do you know those rice paddy hats? The ones shaped just like this radical? That's why this radical is ahat.

mnemonic_image.alt: Conical rice paddy hat that echoes the shape of the radical, two lines meeting to make a broad angle that opens downwards.

name: Favor
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansfavor.

name: Blue
mnemonic: You have life on top of the moon (ignore that life is missing its little slide on the left side). What would life on the moon look like? Well, first of all, they have no air, so they probably look prettybluefrom asphyxiation. When you meet them, it turns out you're right. They're a civilization of blue people. Imagine them all living up there, being blue and Smurfy.

name: Have
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanshave.

name: Ten Thousand
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansten thousand.

name: Hill
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanshill.

name: Table
mnemonic: What happens when you put a flat surface on top of a pair of legs? You get atable.

mnemonic_image.alt: Tall table with book and mug on top. Radical lines overlay table top and legs.

name: Direction
mnemonic: This radical looks like a dude running off to the right. He's heading in a very distinctdirection. Which direction was it again?

mnemonic_image.alt: Man facing to the right with arms outspread, his front leg bent forward as he begins to run. He is pointing in the direction he's about to run in. The radical overlays his silhouette.

name: Feeling
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansfeeling.

name: Child
mnemonic: This is the radical forchild. Aww, see how they're wearing a cap and have their little arms stretched out? You can almost hear them saying "pick me up!" A very child-like child.

mnemonic_image.alt: Young child, their smiling face looking up at you. They wear a cap and have their arms stretched out like a stick figure's. Their body is a vertical line, with shoes at the bottom to match the barb like curl of the radical.

name: Excuse
mnemonic: This radical consists of some legs carrying the sun out of prison. Those legs are yours. When the police stop you, though, what's yourexcuse? Come up with one and say it out loud, starting with, "My excuse is..."

name: Can
mnemonic: It's kind of hard to see, but if you look at this the right way it looks like a tincan. The lines in the middle show the circumference, and the lines on the tops and sides show the outline of the can.

name: Fruit
mnemonic: Everything's about rice in ancient Japan and China. So the rice paddy that is on the tree isn't rice, of course, it's another kind of food. It'sfruit!

name: Alcohol
mnemonic: This looks like the west radical with a little something extra under it… And if you ask for "a little something extra" in the Wild West, you're going to get a big ol' decanter of bourbon, moonshine, or some other kind of very strongalcohol— which happens to be exactly what this radical looks like! That extra line at the bottom is just the little bit of alcohol still left in the bottle.

mnemonic_image.alt: Square bottle of liquor with wide glass stopper, and shallow line of alcohol at bottom. Radical overlays stopper, bottle, and line of alcohol.

name: Hair
mnemonic: These three streaks look like the flowing locks of someone'shair. Pretty easy to see and remember that this is the hair radical, right?

mnemonic_image.alt: Long-haired person facing to the right, their hair flowing out behind them, resembling the three streaks of the radical.

name: Squid
mnemonic: See thesquidshape here? There's its pointy head, its eyes, and its tentacles (two, anyway). Pretty squid-like if you ask me!

mnemonic_image.alt: Squid with large head and short tentacles. Radical lines trace the pointy head, overlay a forehead wrinkle, frame the two eyes, and follow the flaring tentacles.

name: Bed
mnemonic: You'll have to complete the line on the right side in your mind, but see the rectanglebedand the pillows? This is totally a bed. That missing line is where you pulled back the covers when you got up this morning.

mnemonic_image.alt: Overhead view of a bed with two square pillows at the top. The radical outlines the pillows and bed, with a small break in the line at the  bed's right corner, where the covers are pulled back.

name: Concave
mnemonic: It looks like there is a dent in this box. When there is a hole or a dent in something it's calledconcave.

name: Viking
mnemonic: On the top part of the head (冂) radical, there is a horn radical with one extra spike in the middle. This is a horned helmet with one extra spike. Who were famous for having horned helmets like that? The Vikings! That's why this radical is calledViking.

mnemonic_image.alt: A short helmet with two horns on each side curved inward, and one smaller, straight spike in the center. The radical overlays the helmet and three horns.

name: Machine
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansmachine.
Just in case you don't remember this, here's the kanji meaning mnemonic: You have aprivatemouththat's amachine. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you.

name: Sun
mnemonic: Since there are no circles in Japanese characters, sometimes rectangles or squares have to make do. In this case, this big rectangle is thesun. The middle line is a cloud, moving across the sun. Picture it, but don't actually look at the sun and burn your eyes!

mnemonic_image.alt: A shining sun with a thin cloud passing across its middle, outlined by the radical.

name: Meet
mnemonic: Under the hat there are two peoplemeeting in private. Look at them huddled up in there. They must have a reason to want to meet in such a private place, but that's not for you to judge. Maybe next time you have to meet with someone you'll hide under a hat with them too.

mnemonic_image.alt: Conical hat with two bands, center and bottom, radical overlaying its sides and bands. Under it, two people lean inward, one with arm raised in an angle to whisper to the other. The private radical traces their bodies and connecting arm.

name: Happiness
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanshappiness. Don't get it confused with the spicy radical辛, they're very similar!

name: Protect
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansprotect.

name: Cloud
mnemonic:
This is the radical forcloud. See how the cloud is puffy on the bottom but has two lines up top? That's because a plane flew through it.
It was a nice cloud to hang out privately in, until that darn plane came through and ruined it. So much for your private cloud!

mnemonic_image.alt: Airplane flying through top half of tall cloud, two speed lines follow plane’s wings. Radical lines overlay speed lines and private radical under that.

name: Gun
mnemonic: This looks a lot like agunpointing to the right. You have a handle on the left, and the barrel pointing to the right. Imagine it hanging in a case on the wall in a museum.

mnemonic_image.alt: Handgun pointing to the right, its handle and barrel lining up with the radical.

name: Branch
mnemonic: There's a cross branching off of this stool. Since it's branching out, we'll just call this thebranchradical. I guess the tree this stool was made of is coming back to life in the form of a branch.

mnemonic_image.alt: Wooden stool with two legs intersecting under it. A cross shaped tree branch grows out of the seat. The radical overlays the branch and stool seat and legs.

name: Root
mnemonic:
Imagine arootvegetable, like a turnip or something. See the twisted bulb at the top, with long, stringy root tendrils dangling under it? That's why this is the root radical.
Alternatively, focus on the components: sun and kick. When the sun is out, you're outside kicking things around. But be careful — kick a root, and you might trip over it!

mnemonic_image.alt: Bulb of a turnip like root vegetable, with roots growing out of it underneath. Radical overlays bulb and roots.

name: Dog
mnemonic: Remember the big guy who helped you with that big radical? Now you've got his bigDOG! You know it's a dog because he's lying down, legs all spread out, with his favorite bone right beside his head.

mnemonic_image.alt: Overhead view of a dog, its head at the top, its four legs spread out wide, similar to the big radical. An extra stroke to the right of its head, drawn as a bone, completes the dog radical.

name: Stand
mnemonic: This looks like someone in a standing position with legs planted firmly on the ground, spreading their arms out in a T-pose to maintain balance. So that makes this the radical forstand.

mnemonic_image.alt: Person standing, arms held out in a horizontal line matching the radical, two legs under it sloping inward to a ground line, in deliberate standing position.

name: Chapter
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanschapter.

name: Every
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansevery.

name: Prefecture
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansprefecture.

name: Bow
mnemonic: This radical looks like a fancy compositebowpeople would use to shoot at targets and definitely not any normal living animals. See how the middle part is being pulled back? Imagine holding this bow and firing it at a target shaped like a giant alligator-crab monster.

mnemonic_image.alt: Two hands holding a bow and arrow, aimed to the right. The bowstring is being drawn, and the radical shape folds inward with it, outlining the arrow and the arm holding it in the middle of the bow.

name: Both
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansboth.

name: Belt
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansbelt.

name: Doubt
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansdoubt.

name: Zombie
mnemonic: This radical has a figure reaching out both hands at you with some dirt on his head. This is azombie, and he must have just recently dug himself out of the grave by the looks of it.

name: Straight
mnemonic: Oh no, you let the pope's hat get snatched by a lion! You get it back, but it's all crooked, so you've got to make itstraightagain. The pope needs a straight, dignified hat, so you'd better straighten that thing out.

mnemonic_image.alt: Lion’s open mouth with pope hat inside. Animation shows chewed hat followed by straightened one. Radical overlays straight pope hat and L of mouth.

name: Jammed In
mnemonic: This radical looks like a hat with some legs under it. If all you can see is legs, the person wearing the hat must really bejammed inthere. Have you ever tried to cram yourself into a hat so hard it covers your body? Yeah, didn't think so. But imagine how jammed in to that hat you'd be if you did.

mnemonic_image.alt: Person with straw hat pulled down over them, so jammed in to it only their legs are visible. Radical overlays top hat edge and legs.

name: Allocate
mnemonic: You have some legs and you need to put them in the trash. But you'll get caught if you put them in one trash can. Quick, cut them up andallocatethem to different trash cans around the city. Then you'll never get caught.

name: Guard
mnemonic: This radical is made up of horns and older brother. But those aren't really horns, they're a part of your older brother's newguarduniform. He's a guard now, of a bank or a museum. You don't know which, but you know he stands around a lot in his uniform now.

name: Turkey
mnemonic: This is theturkeyradical. It kinda looks like a turkey facing to the left, with big tail feathers fanning out behind it. See it? You can practically hear this thing gobble!

mnemonic_image.alt: A turkey facing to your left, with prominent wing and tail feathers. Radical overlays its head, body, and tail feathers.

name: Sell
mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It meanssell.
Just in case you don't remember, here's the kanji meaning mnemonic: A samurai has come bearing foreheads and legs that he's trying tosell. He thought it was a waste to leave all his slain enemies on the battlefield, so he gathered up their foreheads and legs to sell on the black market for some extra cash. Hey, no judging! A samurai's gotta sell what a samurai's gotta sell, okay?

mnemonic_image.alt: Bust of samurai with sale sign. Under him, top of a forehead and pair of legs. Sell radical overlays samurai, sign, forehead, and legs.

name: Seven
mnemonic: What does this radical look like? Hmm, nothing much. What about if you turn it upside down? Now does it look like a 7 with a line through it? Close enough to help you to remember that this radical isseven, right? Just remember, when you see this radical, flip it over and see what number it looks like. If you can do that, you can remember the meaning!

mnemonic_image.alt: Animation showing the radical being flipped upside down, revealing a shape that looks like the Arabic numeral 7 with a line through it.

name: Name
mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It meansname.

name: Fur
mnemonic: Do you remember the hair radical? This is like that, except now the hair is attached to a tail. Animals don't usually have hair though. Instead, they havefur.

mnemonic_image.alt: Large furry tail, shown vertically, with three horizontal lines passing through it representing tufts of fur on either side. The vertical tail curls up at the bottom to complete the radical shape, and is shown attached to a squirrel.

name: Foot
mnemonic: This is thefootradical. See the person doing a flying dragon kick to the right? What do they hit the target with? Obviously their foot. Imagine that foot coming straight at your face. At that point, your only hope is that it's clean. Nobody wants a foot to the face, especially not a filthy foot.

mnemonic_image.alt: Person with square hair jump kicking, foot and fist outstretched to your right. Opposite foot tucked in, knee up near shoulder. Radical outlines square hair, center of body, legs, and outstretched arm.
